revision.text:
An '''anankastic<ref>From Greek ἀναγκαστικός "compulsory" from ἀνάγκη "necessity."</ref> conditional''' is a [[grammatical construction]] of the form
:''If you want X, you have to do Y.''
where Y is required in order to get X, insisting a peremptory conditionate. For example:
:''If you wanna be my lover, you gotta get with my friends.''<ref>{{citation|title=[[Wannabe (song)|Wannabe]]|author=[[Spice Girls]]|work=[[Spice (album)|Spice]]|year=1996|publisher=[[Virgin Records]]}}</ref>
==Notes== {{reflist}}
==External links== <!--*[http://user.uni-frankfurt.de/~huitink/console13-huitink.pdf Janneke Huitink ''Analyzing anankastic conditionals and sufficiency modals'']--> *[http://mattweiner.net/blog/archives/000146.html Opiniatrety ''If You Want To Get To Sugar Hill in Harlem'']
[[Category:Grammar]] [[Category:Conditionals]]
{{grammar-stub}}

{{Infobox musical artist |name = Bernice Johnson Reagon |image = Bernice-johnson-reagon-sm.jpg |image_size = 130px |caption = |background = solo_singer |birth_name =Bernice Johnson |birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1942|10|4|mf=y}} |death_date = |origin = [[Dougherty County]], [[Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia]]
United States |occupation = singer, songwriter, scholar |instrument = [[singing|vocals]] |genre = [[A cappella]] |years_active = 1966–present |label = |associated_acts = [[Sweet Honey in the Rock]], [[Toshi Reagon]] |website = [http://www.bernicejohnsonreagon.com/ bernicejohnsonreagon.com] }} '''Bernice Johnson Reagon''' (born Bernice Johnson on October 4, 1942) is a song leader, composer, scholar, and [[social activism|social activist]], who in the early 1960s was a founding member of the Student Non-violent Coordinating Committee's (SNCC) [[The Freedom Singers|Freedom Singers]] in the [[Albany Movement]].{{Cite web|url=http://www.georgiaencyclopedia.org/articles/history-archaeology/freedom-singers|title=Freedom Singers|website=New Georgia Encyclopedia|access-date=2017-01-29}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.georgiaencyclopedia.org/articles/history-archaeology/albany-movement|title=Albany Movement|website=New Georgia Encyclopedia|access-date=2017-01-29}} in Georgia. In 1973, she founded the all-black female ''[[a cappella]]'' ensemble [[Sweet Honey in the Rock]], based in Washington, D.C.{{Cite news|url=http://sweethoneyintherock.org/about/bjr/|title=Message from the Founder - Sweet Honey in the Rock®|last=|first=|date=|work=|newspaper=Sweet Honey in the Rock®|language=en-US|quote=First public appearance of Sweet Honey In The Rock at Howard University’s W.C. Handy Blues Festival. The group is Bernice Johnson Reagon, Carol Maillard, Louise Robinson, and Mie.|access-date=2017-01-29|via=}} Reagon, along with other members of the [[SNCC]] Freedom Singers, realized the power of [[collective singing]] to unify the disparate groups who began to work together in the 1964 [[Freedom Summer]] protests in the South.{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=USaWHRykgXoC&pg=PA66&lpg=PA66&dq=albany+singing+movement+paula+giddings&source=bl&ots=papxg4fAX1&sig=SvI9zDPlWgk4c0CtbzCv9EyTM8M&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiry4a1qefRAhWJSiYKHf3jBFIQ6AEIHjAB#v=onepage&q=albany%20singing%20movement%20paula%20giddings&f=false|title=Songs in Black and Lavender: Race, Sexual Politics, and Women's Music|last=Hayes|first=Eileen M.|date=2010-10-01|publisher=University of Illinois Press|year=|isbn=9780252091490|location=|pages=66|language=en|quote=|via=}}
“After a song,” Reagon recalled, “the differences between us were not so great. Somehow, making a song required an expression of that which was common to us all.... This music was like an instrument, like holding a tool in your hand.”{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=HWLwdOmdy9sC&q=albany+singing#v=onepage&q=albany&f=false|title=When and Where I Enter: The Impact of Black Women on Race and Sex in America|last=Giddings|first=Paula J.|date=2009-10-06|publisher=Harper Collins|year=|isbn=9780061984921|location=|pages=279|language=en|quote=|via=}}
The Albany Singing Movement became a vital catalyst for change through music in the early 1960s protests of the Civil Rights era.{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=B2si8EUQ-VkC&pg=PA137&lpg=PA137&dq=albany+singing+movement+paula+giddings&source=bl&ots=Lu2E0LYjq1&sig=7A_wQjX1kBBATBYU-d8dKu5M1wk&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiry4a1qefRAhWJSiYKHf3jBFIQ6AEIHDAA#v=onepage&q=albany%20singing%20movement%20paula%20giddings&f=false|title=Connecting Times: The Sixties in Afro-American Fiction|last=Harris|first=Norman|publisher=Univ. Press of Mississippi|year=1988|isbn=9781617033704|location=Jackson and London|pages=136–7|language=en|quote=|via=}} Reagon devoted her life to [[social justice]] through music via recordings, activism, community singing, and scholarship.{{Cite web|url=http://www.folkways.si.edu/bernice-johnson-reagon-civil-rights-song-leader/african-american-struggle-protest-folk/music/article/smithsonian|title=Bernice Johnson Reagon: Civil Rights song leader|website=Smithsonian Folkways|language=en-US|access-date=2017-01-29}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.allmusic.com/artist/bernice-johnson-reagon-mn0000061050/discography|title=Bernice Johnson Reagon: Album Discography |website=AllMusic|access-date=2017-01-29}}{{Cite web|url=https://www.americanswhotellthetruth.org/portraits/bernice-johnson-reagon|title=Bernice Johnson Reagon |website=Americans Who Tell The Truth|access-date=2017-01-29}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.nebraskapress.unl.edu/product/If-You-Dont-Go-Dont-Hinder-Me,673513.aspx|title=If You Don't Go, Don't Hinder Me|last=Reagon|first=Bernice Johnson|date=|website=University of Nebraska Press|publication-date=2001|access-date=2017-01-29|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170202060551/http://www.nebraskapress.unl.edu/product/If-You-Dont-Go-Dont-Hinder-Me,673513.aspx|archive-date=2017-02-02|dead-url=yes|df=}} She earned her Ph.D. from [[Howard University]] becoming a cultural historian, centered on the role of music, and is an emeritus faculty member in the History Department at [[The American University]].{{Cite web|url=http://www.american.edu/cas/history/faculty/emeritus.cfm|title=Emeritus Faculty with the History Department at American University|website=www.american.edu|language=en|access-date=2017-01-29}} She has also been a scholar-in-residence at [[Stanford University|Stanford]]{{Cite news|url=http://news.stanford.edu/news/2007/march7/reagon-030707.html|title=Bernice Johnson Reagon in residence|newspaper=Stanford University|language=en|access-date=2017-01-29}} and received an honorary doctorate of music from [[Berklee College of Music]].{{Cite web|url=https://www.berklee.edu/news/634/bernice-johnson-reagon-on-freedom-fighting|title=Bernice Johnson Reagon on Freedom Fighting|website=Berklee College of Music|language=en|access-date=2017-01-29}} ==Early life and education== Bernice Johnson was the daughter of Beatrice and J.J. Johnson, a Baptist minister. She was born and raised in southwest Georgia, where church and school were an integrated part of her life, with music heavily intertwined in both of those settings. Reagon began school at the age of three when she was asked by her teacher to attend early, and she passed that first year. By the time she was in the 4th, 5th, and 6th grade, she was requested to tutor students in the 1st, 2nd, and 3rd, and she claims it was because there had only been one teacher. She entered Albany State College in 1959 (since July 1996 [[Albany State University]]) where she began her study of music. She also became active in the local [[NAACP]] chapter and then the [[SNCC]]. After being expelled from Albany State because of an arrest as an activist, she briefly attended [[Spelman College]]. Later, she returned to Spelman to complete her undergraduate degree in 1970. She received a [[Ford Foundation]] fellowship to do graduate study at [[Howard University]], where she was awarded the Ph.D. degree in 1975.{{cite web |url=http://www.georgiaencyclopedia.org/nge/Article.jsp?id=h-2521 | title=Bernice Johnson Reagon | publisher=Georgia Humanities Council | work=New Georgia Encyclopedia | date=2007-11-28 | accessdate=December 10, 2012 | author=Hatfield, Edward A.}} ==Career== ===Activism=== Bernice Johnson Reagon's first demonstration had been in protest against the arrest of Bertha Gober, and Blanton Hall, organized by SNCC along with the initial arrest of the two individuals, for they planned to be arrested in a discussion during a SNCC meeting.{{cite web|title=Interview with Bernice Johnson Reagon|url=http://digital.wustl.edu/cgi/t/text/text-idx?c=eop;cc=eop;rgn=main;view=text;idno=rea0015.0155.086|website=Eyes on The Prize Interviews|publisher=Blackside Inc.|accessdate= March 7, 2018}} Reagon was an active participant in the [[Civil Rights Movement]] of the 1960s. She was a member of The Freedom Singers, organized by the [[Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee]] (SNCC), for which she also served as a field secretary. Reagon explains her first encounter with SNCC as a confusion, for she did not understand the name, or its organization, but she claims that she did understand that they were for freedom and full-time.{{cite web|title=Interview with Bernice Johnson Reagon|website=Eyes on The Prize Interviews|accessdate= March 7, 2018}} The Freedom Singers were organized by [[Cordell Reagon]] in 1962. This group was the first of the civil rights singers to travel nationally. The singers realized that singing helped provide an outlet and unifier for protestors struggling with mob behavior and police brutality. Thanks to her roles with SNCC and the Freedom Singers, Reagon became a highly respected song leader during the Civil Rights Movement. Activist [[James Forman]] later said-"I remember seeing you lift your beautiful black head, stand squarely on your feet, your lips trembling as the melodious words 'Over my head, I see freedom in the air' came forth with an urgency and a pain that brought out a sense of intense renewal and commitment of liberation. And when the call came to protest the jailings, you were up front. You led the line. Your feet hit the dirty pavement with a sureness of direction. You walked proudly onward singing 'this little light of mine, 'and the people echoed, 'shine, shine, shine.'"{{Cite web|url=http://billmoyers.com/2013/05/03/moyers-moment-1991-bernice-johnson-reagon-on-this-little-light-of-mine/|title=Bernice Johnson Reagon on 'This Little Light of Mine'|date=2013-05-03|website=BillMoyers.com|access-date=2017-01-29}} ===Academic=== In 1974, Reagon was appointed as a cultural historian in music history at the [[Smithsonian Institution]], where she directed a program called Black American Culture in 1976,{{cite web|last1=Ida|first1=Jones|title=Guide to the Bernice Johnson Reagon Collection of the African American Sacred Music Tradition, circa 1822-1994|url=http://sova.si.edu/record/NMAH.AC.0653|website=Smithsonian Online Virtual Archives|accessdate=March 7, 2018}} and was later a curator of music history for the [[National Museum of American History]]. Ida Jones from the Smithsonian Institution had stated, "Dr. Reagon collected photographs,sheet music, and other primary and secondary sources chronicling the development of African American sacred music tradition from its birth during the period of slavery through the creation of concert spiritual, gospel music, jazz, and the performance of protest song in the century following Emancipation." on behalf on Reagon's initial job at the museum. In 1989, she was awarded a [[MacArthur Fellowship]]. After Reagon retired in 1993, she continued to work in African American Songs of Protest as a Curator Emeritus. She held an appointment as Distinguished Professor of History at [[American University]] (AU) in Washington DC from 1993 to 2003. Reagon has since been named Professor Emerita of History at AU, and holds the title of Curator Emeritus at the Smithsonian.{{cite web|url=https://www.macfound.org/fellows/368/ |title=Bernice Johnson Reagon |website=MacArthur Foundation |accessdate=2016-01-19 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150919110225/https://www.macfound.org/fellows/368/ |archivedate=2015-09-19 |df= }} ===Music=== Bernice Johnson Reagon claimed that she grew up in a church without a piano, so her early music was A cappella, and her first instruments were her hands and feet, and she explains, "that's the only way I can deal comfortably with creating music." When Reagon speaks upon her upbringing in the musical culture, she explains that even her early schooling was heavily involved with music, not just the church. Reagon says that her teacher would lead the students outside to play games that entailed singing with their hands and feet, as well as their voices.There was also competitions among the students, and Reagon won first place as a child when running against the older students reciting Langston Hughes, "I've Known Rivers".{{cite web|title=Interview with Bernice Johnson Reagon|url=http://digital.wustl.edu/cgi/t/text/text-idx?c=eop;cc=eop;rgn=main;view=text;idno=rea0015.0155.086|website=Eyes on The Prize Interviews|publisher=Blackside Inc.|accessdate=March 7, 2018}} Reagon is a specialist in [[African-American]] oral history, performance and protest traditions. She has served as music consultant, producer, composer, and performer on several award-winning film projects, notably [[PBS]] television productions such as ''[[Eyes on the Prize]]'' (1987) (in which she also appeared) and [[Ken Burns]]' ''[[The Civil War (TV series)|The Civil War]]'' (1990). Reagon was also featured in a film, "We Shall Overcome" which was about the song and its placement in the movement, being produced by Ginger Records and made by Henry Hampton, the same creator of Eyes on The Prize. She was the conceptual producer and narrator of the [[Peabody Award]]-winning radio series, ''Wade in the Water, African American Sacred Music Traditions.''{{citation needed|date=February 2017}} Bernice Johnson Reagon claimed, "These days, I come as a 'songtalker', one who balances talk and song in the creation of a live performance conversation with those who gather within the sound of my voice."{{cite web|last1=Reagon|first1=Bernice Johnson|url=https://www.facebook.com/Bernice-Johnson-Reagon-188881438633/|title=Bernice Reagon|website=Facebook|accessdate=March 7, 2018}} Reagon joined her first and only gospel choir when she was eleven years old, which was organized by her sister at the Mt. Early Baptist Church. She and the choir would listen to the local radio station WGPC to learn black gospel for the choir to recite. As a child, the Five Blind Guys was her favorite quartet. Reagon states that her role models in terms of music are Harriet Tubman, Sojourner Truth, and Bessie Jones, because they assisted her understanding of traditional singing and the fight for justice. She also sees Deacon Reardon as an importance to her work as a historian studying African American sacred worship traditions, and she states that he impacted both her spiritual and musical development.{{cite book|last1=Reagon|first1=Bernice Johnson|title=If You Don't Go, Don't Hinder me The African American Sacred Song tradition|date=1942|publisher=Lincoln: University of Nebraska Press|isbn=1-280-51030-7|pages=100–140|url=https://ebookcentral.proquest.com/lib/pierce-ebooks/reader.action?docID=3039267&query=|accessdate=March 7, 2018}} Reagon's work as a scholar and composer is reflected in her publications on African-American culture and history, including: a collection of essays entitled ''If You Don’t Go, Don’t Hinder Me: The African American Sacred Song Tradition'' (University of Nebraska Press, 2001); ''We Who Believe In Freedom: Sweet Honey In The Rock: Still on the Journey'', (Anchor Books, 1993); and ''We'll Understand It Better By And By: Pioneering African American Gospel Composers'' (Smithsonian Press, 1992). Reagon has recorded several albums on [[Folkways Records]] including ''Folk Songs: The South,'' ''Wade in the Water,'' and ''Lest We Forget, Vol. 3: Sing for Freedom.''[http://www.folkways.si.edu/searchresults.aspx?sPhrase=bernice%20reagon&sType='phrase'/ Bernice Johnson Reagon Discography on Folkways]{{dead link|date=November 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}. Folkways.si.edu. Retrieved on 2011-12-09. In 1973 Reagon founded the six-member, all-female [[a cappella]] group entitled 'Sweet Honey in the Rock.' In addition to Reagon, the women in the original group were: Ysaye Maria Barnwell, Nitanju Bolade Casle, Shirley Childress Johnson, Aisha Kahil, and Carol Maillard. The only instrument they used was their voices, along with shekere and tambourine. They have toured internationally, including to Europe, Japan, Mexico, and Australia. The group's fan base is of different ethnic backgrounds, religions, and sexual orientations. Reagon's musical roots come from the rural South Baptist Church. She has advocated "music's informational and transformative power to ask" and the strong effects that music has had on the Civil Rights Movement.{{citation needed|date=July 2014}} ==Honors== *In 1991 Reagon received a [[Candace Award]] from the [[National Coalition of 100 Black Women]].{{cite news |newspaper=The New York Times |title=Chronicle |date=June 26, 1991 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/26/style/chronicle-949991.html}} *In 1995 she received a [[Charles Frankel Prize]] for her contributions to the public understanding of the [[humanities]]. The award was presented at the [[White House]] by [[Bill Clinton|President Bill Clinton]]. *Other notable awards include the 9th Annual [[Heinz Award]] in the Arts and Humanities given in 2003.[http://www.heinzawards.net/recipients/bernice-johnson-reagon The Heinz Awards, Bernice Johnson Reagon profile] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161020090222/http://www.heinzawards.net/recipients/bernice-johnson-reagon |date=October 20, 2016 }}. Heinzawards.net. Retrieved on 2011-12-09 In April 2009 Reagon received an honorary doctoral degree from the Berklee College of Music. In 2000 she won the First National Leeway Laurel Award at the Leeway Foundation in Philadelphia. *In 1996 Reagon won the Isadora Duncan Award. ==Personal life== In 1963 she married [[Cordell Reagon]], another member of The Freedom Singers.Hopkinson, Natalie {{cite web |url=http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_qa4081/is_200309/ai_n9297789 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060316202930/http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_qa4081/is_200309/ai_n9297789 |dead-url=yes |archive-date=March 16, 2006 |title=Solid Rock |accessdate=August 30, 2016}}. Crisis, The. Sep/Oct 2003 Their daughter [[Toshi Reagon]] is also a singer-songwriter. Reagon believes that "Life's challenges are not supposed to paralyze you, they're supposed to help you discover who you are." She believes that black people have created their own world. African Americans had to use what ever territory at their disposal to create a people. And that territory wasn't land, it was culture. She also said there was so much done because black culture was the only thing black people could call their own. That is why she feels black culture is the most powerful in the world.{{cite book|last1=Brown|first1=Leonard|title=John Coltrane and Black Americas Quest for Freedom: Spirituality and the Music|date=11 August 2010|publisher=Oxford University Press|isbn=0199779740|pages=23–24|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=RzZwGWRRz1UC&lpg=PA24&ots=uFfsZq9oD6&dq=black%20culture%20is%20the%20most%20powerful%20in%20the%20world%20bernice%20johnson%20reagon&pg=PA24#v=onepage&q=black%20culture%20is%20the%20most%20powerful%20in%20the%20world%20bernice%20johnson%20reagon&f=false|accessdate=18 January 2016}} ==See also== * [[Women's music]] * [[Black feminism]] * [[Freedom Singers]] * [[Sweet Honey in the Rock]] * [[Smithsonian Folkways]] * [[Protest songs in the United States|Protest song]] ==References== {{Reflist}} * Buffalo, Audreen. "Sweet Honey: A Cappella Activists." ''Ms'' 03 1993: 24. ProQuest. Web. 17 May 2014 . * Dr. Bernice Johnson Reagon 1999 Folk Alliance International Lifetime Achievement Award Recipient. Performer, Dr. Bernice Johnson Reagon. Folk Alliance International, 2 Sept. 2011. Web. 12 May 2014. * Reagon, Bernice J. "Bernice Johnson Reagon." Music: Freedom Singers. Songtalk Publishing. Web. 13 May 2014. * "Bernice Johnson Reagon." Smithsonian Folkways. Smithsonian Institution, n.d. Web. 16 May 2014. ==External links== * [http://www.bernicejohnsonreagon.com Official website] * [https://snccdigital.org/people/bernice-johnson-reagon/ SNCC Digital Gateway: Bernice Johnson Reagon], Documentary website created by the SNCC Legacy Project and Duke University, telling the story of the Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee & grassroots organizing from the inside-out * [http://heinzawards.net/recipients/bernice-johnson-reagon The Heinz Awards, Bernice Johnson Reagon profile] {{African-American Civil Rights Movement|state=collapsed}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Reagon, Bernice Johnson}} [[Category:1942 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:African-American singers]] [[Category:Activists for African-American civil rights]] [[Category:African and Black nationalism in the United States]] [[Category:American academics]] [[Category:American activists]] [[Category:American female singers]] [[Category:American folk singers]] [[Category:American gospel singers]] [[Category:American University faculty and staff]] [[Category:Baptists from the United States]] [[Category:Feminist musicians]] [[Category:Howard University alumni]] [[Category:MacArthur Fellows]] [[Category:Singers from Georgia (U.S. state)]] [[Category:National Humanities Medal recipients]] [[Category:Spelman College alumni]] [[Category:Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee]] [[Category:20th-century American musicians]] [[Category:21st-century American musicians]] [[Category:Women's music]] [[Category:20th-century women singers]] [[Category:Sweet Honey in the Rock members]]

[[File:Spas vsederzhitel sinay.jpg|thumbnail|Christ Pantocrator from [[Saint Catherine's Monastery]] in [[Sinai]].]] '''The Christ Pantocrator of St. Catherine’s Monastery at Sinai''' is one of the oldest [[Roman Empire|Eastern Roman]] religious [[icon]]s, dating from the sixth century AD.<ref>John Galey, George Forsyth, and Kurt Weitzmann, ''Sinai and the Monastery of St. Catherine'' (Givatayim, Israel: Massada, 1980), 99.</ref> It is the earliest known version of the [[Christ Pantocrator|pantocrator style]] that still survives today, and is regarded by historians and scholars to be one of the most important and recognizable works in the study of [[Byzantine art]] as well as [[Eastern Orthodox Church|Eastern Orthodox Christianity]].<ref>Galey, Forsyth, Weitzmann, ''Sinai'', 92.</ref>
== Background ==
For a time the icon was thought to have been dated from the thirteenth century, since it had been almost completely painted over at that time, but it was concluded in 1962 that it is in fact from the mid-sixth century, although the exact date of production is still unknown.<ref>Kurt Weitzmann, ''The Monastery of Saint Catherine at Mount Sinai, the Icons'' (Princeton, N.J.: Princeton University Press, 1976), 13.</ref> When [[Saint Catherine's Monastery|Saint Catherine’s Monastery]] was founded by the Byzantine emperor [[Justinian I]], late in his reign, between 548 and 565,<ref>Galey, Forsyth, Weitzmann, ''Sinai'', 13.</ref> it enjoyed imperial patronage and donations from Justinian and his court, with the Christ Pantocrator icon having been one of the many possible imperial gifts.<ref>Galey, Forsyth, Weitzmann, ''Sinai'', 92; Kōnstantinos A. Manaphēs, ''Sinai: Treasures of the Monastery of Saint Catherine'' (Athens: Ekdotike Athenon, 1990), 93.</ref> Because of this, it is generally believed to have been produced in the Byzantine capital of [[Constantinople]].<ref>Galey, Forsyth, Weitzmann, Sinai, 92.</ref>
== Interpretation and meaning == {{see also|Christ Pantocrator}}
[[File:Composite_christ_pantocrator.png|thumb|Mirrored composites of left and right sides of image]]
Many agree that the icon represents the [[Hypostatic union|dual nature of Christ]], illustrating traits of both man and god,<ref>Manolis Chatzidakis and Gerry Walters, “An Encaustic Icon of Christ at Sinai,” ''The Art Bulletin'' 49, No. 3 (1967): 201; Galey, Forsyth, Weitzmann, ''Sinai'', 92; Manaphēs 93; Weitzmann, ''Sinai, the Icons'', 15.</ref> perhaps influenced by the aftermath of the [[ecumenical council|ecumenical councils]] of the previous century at [[First Council of Ephesus|Ephesus]] and [[Council of Chalcedon|Chalcedon]].<ref>Manaphēs, ''Sinai: Treasures'', 84; Robin Cormack, ''Oxford History of Art: Byzantine Art'' (Oxford: Oxford University Press, 2000), 66.</ref> Christ’s features on the left side{{clarify |date=March 2018 |reason=Is that *his* left side, or the left side of the painting?}} are supposed to represent the qualities of his human nature, while the right side represents his divinity.<ref>Weitzmann, ''Sinai, the Icons'', 15.</ref> His right hand is shown opening outward, signifying his gift of blessing, while the left hand and arm is clutching a thick [[Gospel]] book.<ref>Chatzidakis and Walters, “An Encaustic Icon,” 201.</ref>
Some scholars have suggested the icon at Sinai could have been a possible representation of the Kamouliana icon of Christ<ref>Cormack, ''Byzantine Art'', 78-9; Manaphēs, ''Sinai: Treasures'', 93.</ref> or of the famous icon of Christ of the [[Chalke Gate]],<ref>Chatzidakis and Walters, “An Encaustic Icon,” 202.</ref> an image which was destroyed twice during the first and second waves of [[Byzantine Iconoclasm]]{{mdash}}first in 726, and again in 814{{mdash}}and thus its connection with the Christ Pantocrator is difficult to confirm.<ref>Weitzmann, ''Sinai, the Icons'', 14.</ref>
== Description and production ==
With a height of 84 cm, width of 45.5 cm, and a thickness of 1.2 cm, the icon was originally taller and wider before its top and sides were cut.<ref>Weitzmann, ''Sinai, the Icons'', 13.</ref> Otherwise there is only one spot with major damage, a large portion of Christ’s hair on his left side, including his left ear and shoulder.<ref>Weitzmann, ''Sinai, the Icons'', 13.</ref> The original [[Encaustic painting|encaustic]] surface has continually been preserved in excellent condition overall.<ref>Weitzmann, ''Sinai, the Icons'', 13.</ref> As with many of the early icons from Sinai, the Christ Pantocrator was created by using this technique, known as encaustic—a medium using hot wax paint—that would rarely continue to be utilized in the Byzantine world after the iconoclastic controversies of the eighth and ninth centuries.<ref>Cormack, ''Byzantine Art'', 111-2.</ref> In fact, the monastery at Sinai is the only place in the world where a substantial number of these encaustic icons, particularly those dating from as early as the sixth century, have been preserved.<ref>Galey, Forsyth, Weitzmann, ''Sinai'', 91.</ref> During the Period of Byzantine [[Iconoclasm]], the production of Orthodox icons continued at Sinai, whereas they were being destroyed in Constantinople.<ref>Galey, Forsyth, Weitzmann, ''Sinai'', 92-3.</ref>
== Survival from Byzantine Iconoclasm and aftermath == The Muslim Arabs [[Early Muslim conquests|quickly took control]] of the entire [[Fertile Crescent]] south of the Turkish mountains, including Egypt and Sinai, cutting the monastery’s ties with Constantinople in the year 640.<ref>Galey, Forsyth, Weitzmann, ''Sinai'', 92.</ref> Therefore, by the time the era of iconoclasm had been initiated by [[Leo III the Isaurian|Emperor Leo III]] in 726, the Monastery of Saint Catherine had already been protected under [[caliphate|Muslim rule]] for nearly a century and was able to survive the destruction of iconoclasm.<ref>Kurt Weitzmann, “The Mosaic in St. Catherine’s Monastery on Mount Sinai,” ''Proceedings of the American Philosophical Society'' 110, No. 6 (Dec. 1966): 405; Galey, Forsyth, Weitzmann, ''Sinai'', 92; Manaphēs, ''Sinai: Treasures'', 92.</ref> Furthermore, the location of the monastery in the rocky desert of Sinai, far away from any major trade or military route, kept the contents within St. Catherine’s safe from raiders as well as conquering armies.<ref>Weitzmann, “Mosaic in St. Catherine’s,” 392; Galey, Forsyth, Weitzmann, ''Sinai'', 49.</ref> Even today the monastery houses more than 2,000 icons, dating from the sixth century to the modern times.<ref>Galey, Forsyth, Weitzmann, ''Sinai'', 99.</ref>
== Notes ==
{{reflist|2}}
== Bibliography ==
*Chatzidakis, Manolis and Walters, Gerry. “An Encaustic Icon of Christ at Sinai.” ''The Art Bulletin'' 49, No. 3 (1967): 197-208. *Cormack, Robin. ''Oxford History of Art: Byzantine Art''. Oxford: Oxford University Press, 2000. *Galey, John, Forsyth, George, and Weitzmann, Kurt. ''Sinai and the Monastery of St. Catherine''. Givatayim, Israel: Massada, 1980. *Manaphēs, Kōnstantinos A. ''Sinai: Treasures of the Monastery of Saint Catherine''. Athens: Ekdotike Athenon, 1990. *Weitzmann, Kurt. “The Mosaic in St. Catherine’s Monastery on Mount Sinai.” ''Proceedings of the American Philosophical Society'' 110, No. 6 (Dec. 1966): 392-405. *Weitzmann, Kurt. ''The Monastery of Saint Catherine at Mount Sinai, the Icons''. Princeton, N.J.: Princeton University Press, 1976.
== Further reading ==
*Coleman, Simon and Elsner, John. “The Pilgrim’s Progress: Art, Architecture and Ritual Movement at Sinai.” ''World Archaeology'' 26, No. 1 (1994): 73-89. *Nelson, Robert S., Collins, Kristen M., and J. Paul Getty Museum. ''Holy Image, Hallowed Ground: Icons from Sinai''. Los Angeles: J. Paul Getty Museum, 2006.

page.title: Cuban immigration to the United States

revision.text:
'''Cuban immigration to the United States''', for the most part, occurred in two periods: the first series of [[immigration]] of [[Cuban American]]s from [[Cuba]] to the [[United States]] resulted from Cubans establishing [[cigar]] factories in [[Tampa, Florida|Tampa]] and from attempts to overthrow Spanish colonial rule by the movement led by [[José Martí]], the second to escape from [[Communist state|Communist rule]] under [[Fidel Castro]] following the [[Cuban Revolution]]. Massive [[Cuban migration to Miami]] during the second series led to major demographic and cultural changes in Miami. There was also [[Economic migrant|economic emigration]], particularly during the [[Great Depression]] in the 1930s.
The [[Louisiana Purchase]] and the [[Adams–Onís Treaty]] of 1819, [[Spanish Florida]], including the present day state of [[Florida]] and, at times, [[Louisiana]] and adjoining territory, was a province of the [[Captaincy General of Cuba]] (Captain General being the Spanish title equivalent to the British colonial Governor). Consequently, Cuban immigration to the U.S. has a long history, beginning in the [[Spanish colonization of the Americas|Spanish colonial period]] in 1565 when [[St. Augustine, Florida]] was established by [[Pedro Menéndez de Avilés]], and hundreds of Spanish-Cuban soldiers and their families moved from Cuba to St. Augustine to establish a new life.
Thousands of Cuban settlers also immigrated to Louisiana between 1778 and 1802 and [[Texas]] during the period of Spanish rule.{{citation needed|date=April 2011}} Since 1820 the Cuban presence was more than 1000 people. In 1870 the number of Cuban immigrants increased to almost 12,000, of which 4,500 resided in [[New York City]], 3,000 in [[New Orleans]], and 2,000 in [[Key West, Florida|Key West]]. The causes of these movements were both economic and political, which intensified after 1860, when political factors played the predominant role in emigration, as a result of deteriorating relations with the Spanish metropolis.
The year 1869 marked the beginning of one of the most significant periods of emigration from Cuba to the United States, again centered on Key West. The exodus of hundreds of workers and businessmen was linked to the manufacture of tobacco. The reasons are many: the introduction of more modern techniques of elaboration of snuff, the most direct access to its main market, the United States, the uncertainty about the future of the island, which had suffered years of economic, political and social unrest during the beginning of the Ten Years' War against Spanish rule. It was an exodus of skilled workers, precisely the class in the island that had succeeded in establishing a free labor sector amid a slave economy.
The manufacture of snuff by the Cuban labor force, became the most important source of income for Key West between 1869 and 1900.
Tampa was added to such efforts, with a strong migration of Cubans, which went from 720 inhabitants in 1880 to 5,532 in 1890. However, the second half of the 1890s marked the decline of the Cuban immigrant population, as an important part of it returned to the island to fight for independence. The War accentuated Cuban immigrant integration into American society, whose numbers were significant: more than 12,000 people.<ref name="Cubabloqueo">[https://archive.is/20130210003916/http://www.cubavsbloqueo.cu/Default.aspx?tabid=2204 Cuba vs Bloqueo] (In Spanish). Posted by Dr. Antonio Aja Díaz – CEMI (Centro de Estudios de la Migración Internacional- Center for the Study of International Migration) July 2000</ref>
[[File:Jose marti in ybor.JPG|right|175px|thumb|Statue of Jose Martí at the [[Circulo Cubano de Tampa|Circulo Cubano (Cuban Club)]], Ybor City]]
== Key West and Tampa, Florida == In the mid-to late 19th century, several cigar manufacturers moved their operations to [[Key West]] to get away from growing disruptions as Cubans sought independence from Spanish colonial rule. Many Cuban cigar workers followed. The Cuban government had even established a grammar school in Key West to help preserve Cuban culture. There, children learned folk songs and patriotic hymns such as "[[La Bayamesa]]", the Cuban national anthem.
In 1885, [[Vicente Martinez Ybor]] moved his cigar operations from Key West to the town of [[Tampa, Florida]] to escape labor strife. [[History of Ybor City|Ybor City]] was designed as a modified [[company town]], and it quickly attracted thousands of Cuban workers from Key West and Cuba. [[West Tampa]], another cigar manufacturing community, was founded nearby in 1892 and grew quickly. Between these communities, the [[Tampa Bay area]]'s Cuban population grew from almost nothing to the largest in Florida in just over a decade, and the city as a whole grew from a village of 1,000 residents in 1885 to over 16,000 by 1900.
Both Ybor City and West Tampa were instrumental in Cuba's eventual independence.<ref>{{cite book |ref=harv |last=Westfall |first=Loy G. |title=Tampa Bay: Cradle of Cuban Liberty |publisher=Key West Cigar City USA |year=2000 |isbn=978-0-9668948-2-0}}</ref> Inspired by revolutionaries such as [[Jose Martí]], who visited Florida several times, Tampa-area Cubans and their neighbors donated money, equipment, and sometimes their lives to the cause of ''Cuba Libre''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nps.gov/history/nr/twhp/wwwlps/lessons/51ybor/51facts3.htm |title=Ybor City: Cigar Capital of the World-Reading 3 |publisher=Nps.gov |date= |accessdate=2010-08-08}}</ref> After the [[Spanish–American War]], some Cubans returned to Cuba, but others chose to stay in the U.S. due to the physical and economic devastation caused by conflicte on the island.<ref>{{cite book |last=Lastra |first=Frank |title=Ybor City: The Making of a Landmark Town |publisher=University of Tampa Press |year=2006 |isbn=978-1-59732-003-0}}</ref>
== Early emigration – 1900–59 == Several other small waves of Cuban emigration to the U.S. occurred in the early 20th century (1900–59). Most settled in Florida and the northeast U.S. The majority of the 100,000 Cubans came for economic reasons due to (the Great Depression of 1929, volatile sugar prices, and migrant farm labor contracts).{{Citation needed|date=March 2011}} Others included anti-Batista refugees fleeing the military dictatorship, which had pro-U.S. diplomatic ties. During the '20s and '30s, emigration basically comprised workers looking for jobs, mainly in New York and New Jersey. They were classified as labor migrants and workers, much like other immigrants in the area at that time. Thus migrated more than 40,000 in the first decade, encouraged by U.S. immigration facilities at the time and more than 43,000 by the end of the 30s.{{citation needed|date=December 2013}}
Subsequently, the flow of Cubans to the United States fluctuated, due to both the domestic situation in the 40s and 50s in Cuba, and U.S. immigration policies, plus intermittent anti-immigrant sentiment. Cuban migration in those years included persons who could afford to leave the country and live abroad.{{citation needed|date=December 2013}}
The Cuban population officially registered in the United States for 1958 was around 125,000 people, including descendants. Of these, more than 50,000 remained in the United States after the revolution of 1959.<ref name="Cubabloqueo"/>
== Post-Castro revolution (1959–)== After the [[Cuban revolution]] led by [[Fidel Castro]] in 1959, a Cuban exodus began as the new government allied itself with the Soviet Union and began to introduce communism. From 1960 to 1979, hundreds of thousands of Cubans left Cuba. Most came from Cuba's educated upper and middle classes. Between December 1960 and October 1962 more than 14,000 Cuban children arrived alone in the U.S {{citation needed|date=July 2018}}.
[[Operacion Pedro Pan]] developed when children arrived in Miami and were met by representatives of Catholic Charities. The children were then sent to live with relatives, foster homes, orphanages, or boarding schools. In order to provide aid to the immigrants, the [[United States Congress]] passed the [[Cuban Adjustment Act]] in 1966. The Cuban Refugee Program provided more than $1.3 billion of direct financial assistance. They also were eligible for [[public assistance]], [[Medicare (United States)|Medicare]], free English courses, [[scholarship]]s, and low-interest college [[loan]]s.{{citation needed|date=December 2013}}
Some banks pioneered loans for exiles who did not have collateral or credit but received help in getting a business loan. These loans helped many Cuban Americans to secure funds and start up their own businesses. With their Cuban-owned businesses and low cost of living, [[Miami|Miami, Florida]] and [[Union City, New Jersey]] (dubbed ''[[Havana on the Hudson]])''<ref name=NYTimes2.5.06>Gettleman, Jeffrey (February 5, 2006). [https://select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F30F13F7345B0C768CDDAB0894DE404482 "ON POLITICS; A Cuban Revolution, Only It's in New Jersey"]. ''[[The New York Times]]''.</ref><ref>Bartlett, Kay. [https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1129&dat=19770628&id=4kwNAAAAIBAJ&sjid=U20DAAAAIBAJ&pg=4464,3136176 "Little Havana on the Hudson], posted in the ''[[Pittsburgh Post-Gazette]]'' on June 28, 1977. Accessed March 31, 2011.</ref> were the preferred destinations for many immigrants and soon became the main centers for Cuban American culture. According to author Lisandro Perez, Miami was not particularly attractive to Cubans prior to the 1960s.<ref>Grenier, Guillermo J. [https://books.google.com/books?id=3XBcqhL_pKEC&pg=PA84&lpg=PA84&dq=miami+destination+for+cubans&source=bl&ots=SG9mwO2HvT&sig=LG-gcvjtZAjbJF3gfyQJdUtD0KQ&hl=en&ei=RPMhSu_6OY3htgeoyYHQBg&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1 ''Miami Now!: Immigration, Ethnicity, and Social Change'']. Retrieved March 31, 2011.</ref>
It was not until the exodus of the Cuban exiles in 1959 that Miami became a preferred location. [[Westchester, Florida]] within [[Miami-Dade County, Florida|Miami-Dade County]], was the area most densely populated by Cubans and Cuban Americans in the United States, followed by [[Hialeah, Florida]] in second.<ref name=MDFLCuba>{{cite web |url=http://www.epodunk.com/ancestry/Cuban.html |title=Ancestry Map of Cuban Communities |publisher=Epodunk.com |accessdate=2007-12-23}}</ref>
Communities like Miami, Tampa, and Union City, which Cuban Americans made their home, experienced a profound cultural impact as a result, as seen in such aspects of their local culture as cuisine, fashion, music, entertainment and [[cigar]]-making.<ref>Martin, Lydia (August 9, 1995). "Cuban cool" ''[[The Star-Ledger]]''. pp. 41 and 54.</ref><ref>Juri, Carmen (August 9, 1995). "Jersey's Cuban flavors" ''The Star-Ledger''. p, 41 and 54.</ref>
===Mid-1990s to 2000s=== In the mid-1990s, after the implementation of the "[[wet feet, dry feet]]" policy, immigration patterns changed. Many Cuban immigrants departed from the southern and western coasts and arrived at the [[Yucatán Peninsula]] in [[Mexico]] while others landed on [[Isla Mujeres]]. From there they went to the [[Mexico–United States border|Texas–Mexico border]] to request asylum. Many of the Cubans who did not have family in Miami settled in [[Houston]]; this has caused Houston's Cuban American community to increase in size.The term "dusty foot" refers to Cubans emigrating to the U.S. through Mexico. In 2005 the [[United States Department of Homeland Security|Department of Homeland Security]] had abandoned the approach of detaining every dry foot Cuban who crosses through Texas and began a policy allowing most Cubans to obtain immediate parole.<ref>Russell Cobb and Paul Knight. [http://www.houstonpress.com/2008-01-10/news/immigration-cubans-enter-u-s-at-texas-mexico-border/ "Immigration: Cubans Enter U.S. at Texas-Mexico Border"], ''[[Houston Press]]'', January 9, 2008</ref>
Jorge Ferragut, a Cuban immigrant who founded Casa Cuba, an agency that assists Cuban immigrants arriving in Texas, said in a 2008 article that many Cuban immigrants of the first decade of the 21st century left due to economic instead of political issues.<ref>"Immigration: Cubans Enter U.S. at Texas-Mexico Border." ''[[Houston Press]]''. [http://www.houstonpress.com/2008-01-10/news/immigration-cubans-enter-u-s-at-texas-mexico-border/3 3].</ref> By October 2008 Mexico and Cuba created an agreement to prevent immigration of Cubans through Mexico.<ref>Knight, Paul. [http://blogs.houstonpress.com/hairballs/2008/10/immigration_cuba_mexico.php "Cuba, Mexico Look To Block The Texas Entrance To The U.S."], ''[[Houston Press]]'', October 20, 2008</ref><ref>Olsen, Alexandra. [http://www.themonitor.com/articles/mexico_18862___article.html/cuban_cubans.html "Cuba: Mexico to fight illegal migration to US"], [[Associated Press]] via ''[[The Monitor (Texas)|The Monitor]]'', October 20, 2008</ref>
[[Puerto Rico]] also become a destination for Cubans trying to reach the United States. As a U.S. [[Commonwealth (U.S. insular area)|Commonwealth]], Puerto Rico was seen as a stepping stone for emigration.<ref>[http://www.dominicantoday.com/app/article.aspx?id=16234 "Cubans using Haitian, Dominican soil to reach Puerto Rico concerns the U.S."] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071112075240/http://www.dominicantoday.com/app/article.aspx?id=16234 |date=2007-11-12 }}, ''Dominican Today'', accessed 20 April 2007</ref>
===Immigration policy=== Before the 1980s, all refugees from Cuba were welcomed into the United States as political refugees. This changed in the 1990s so that only Cubans who reach U.S. soil were granted refuge status under the "[[wet feet, dry feet policy|wet foot, dry foot policy]]". While representing a tightening of U.S. immigration policy, the wet foot, dry foot policy afforded Cubans a privileged position relative to other immigrants to the U.S.
According to a U.S. Census 1970 report, Cuban Americans lived in all 50 states. But as later Census reports demonstrated, most Cuban immigrants settled in south Florida. A new trend in the late 1990s showed that fewer immigrants arrived from Cuba than previously. While U.S. born Cuban Americans moved out of their enclaves, other nationalities settled there.{{citation needed|date=December 2013}}
==Notes and references== {{reflist}}
[[Category:Immigration to the United States]]

{{Infobox spaceflight | name = Deimos-2 | image = | image_caption = | mission_type = [[Remote sensing]] | operator = [[Deimos Imaging]] | website = {{url|http://www.elecnor-deimos.com/portfolio/deimos-2/}} | COSPAR_ID = 2014-033D | SATCAT = | mission_duration = 7 years | spacecraft_bus = [[SI-300]] | manufacturer = [[Satrec Initiative]] | dry_mass = | launch_mass = ~{{convert|310|kg|lb}} | dimensions = {{convert|1200|x|1200|mm|in}}
(Hexagonal) | power = 330 watts | launch_date = {{start-date|June 19, 2014, 19:11|timezone=yes}} UTC | launch_rocket = [[Dnepr (rocket)|Dnepr]] | launch_site = [[Dombarovsky (air base)|Dombarovsky]] [[Dombarovsky Site 370|370/13]] | launch_contractor = [[ISC Kosmotras|Kosmotras]] | last_contact = | decay_date = | orbit_epoch = 27 June 2014{{cite web |last=McDowell |first=Jonathan |title=SATCAT |url=http://planet4589.org/space/log/satcat.txt |publisher=Jonathan's Space Pages |accessdate=3 May 2018}} | orbit_reference = [[geocentric orbit|Geocentric]] | orbit_regime = [[sun-synchronous orbit|Sun-Synchronous]] | orbit_periapsis = {{convert|597|km|mi}} | orbit_apoapsis = {{convert|617|km|mi}} | orbit_inclination = 97.9 degrees | orbit_period = | apsis = gee | instrument_type = camera | telescope_name = [[Dubai Medium Aperture Camera|DMAC]] | telescope_wavelength = '''Pan:''' 420-720 nm
'''MS1:''' 420-510 nm (Blue)
'''MS2:''' 510-580 nm (Green)
'''MS3:''' 600-720 nm (Red)
'''MS4:''' 760-890 nm (Near Infrared) | telescope_resolution = {{convert|0.75|m}} (Pan)
{{convert|5|m}} (MS) }} '''Deimos-2''' is a Spanish [[remote sensing]] [[satellite|Earth observation satellite]] built for [[Elecnor Deimos]] under an agreement with [[Satrec Initiative]], a satellite manufacturing company in [[South Korea]]. The Earth observation system was developed by [[Elecnor Deimos]], who managed the engineering, ground segment, integration, tests, launch contract and [[LEOP]], in collaboration with [[Satrec Initiative]], who provided the platform and the payload{{cite web|url=https://spacedata.copernicus.eu/web/cscda/missions/deimos-2|title=DEIMOS-2|website=spacedata.copernicus.eu}}. The platform is based on [[DubaiSat-2]] launched in 2013, with a larger battery pack intended to last for at least 7 years.{{cite web|url=http://www.gsdi.org/gsdiconf/gsdi14/slides/4.2Deimos.pdf|title=GSDI - Home|first=Roger Longhorn|last=(Admin)|website=www.gsdi.org}} The satellite was purchased by [[Urthecast]] in 2015, together with [[Deimos-1]] and [[Deimos Imaging]], the division of [[Elecnor Deimos]] that was in charge of the operation of both satellites{{cite web|url=http://spacenews.com/urthecast-buying-deimos-imaging-division-and-its-2-satellites/|title=Urthecast Buying Deimos' Imaging Division and its 2 Satellites|date=23 June 2015|publisher=}}. Deimos-2 is currently property of [[Deimos Imaging]], who operates it and commercialises its data.{{-}} ==See also== {{Portal|Spaceflight}} * [[2014 in spaceflight]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.oriondata-i.com/ Oriondata Internacional] – reseller of Deimos-1, Deimos-2 in Chile and others countries in Latin America * [http://www.elecnor-deimos.com/portfolio/deimos-2/ Deimos-2] {{Space program of Spain}} {{Orbital launches in 2014}} {{Use British English|date=January 2014}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Deimos-2}} [[Category:Spacecraft launched in 2014]] [[Category:Satellites of South Korea]] [[Category:Satellites of Spain]] [[Category:Remote sensing]] [[Category:Earth observation satellites]] [[Category:Spacecraft launched by Dnepr rockets]] {{Spain-spacecraft-stub}}
