page.title: Feminist art movement in the United States

revision.text:
[[File:Guerrilla girls MOMA.jpg|thumb|upright=1.2|Guerilla girls exhibit, Museum of Modern Art (MoMA)]] {{Feminism sidebar}}
The '''feminist art movement in the United States''' began in the early 1970s and sought to promote the study, creation, understanding and promotion of women's art. First-generation feminist artists include [[Judy Chicago]], [[Miriam Schapiro]], [[Suzanne Lacy]], [[Judith Bernstein]], [[Sheila Levrant de Bretteville|Sheila de Bretteville]], [[Mary Beth Edelson]], [[Carolee Schneeman]], [[Rachel Rosenthal]], and many other women. They were part of the [[Feminist art movement]] in the United States in the early 1970s to develop feminist writing and art.<ref>{{cite book |author1=Thomas Patin |author2=Jennifer McLerran |lastauthoramp=yes | title=Artwords: A Glossary of Contemporary Art Theory |location=Westport, CT | publisher=Greenwood | year=1997 |page=55 | url=https://www.questia.com/read/27960870 |accessdate=8 January 2014 }} via [[Questia]] (subscription required)</ref> The movement spread quickly through museum protests in both New York (May 1970) and Los Angeles (June 1971), via an early network called W.E.B. ([[West-East Bag]]) that disseminated news of feminist art activities from 1971 to 1973 in a nationally circulated newsletter, and at conferences such as the West Coast Women's Artists Conference held at [[California Institute of the Arts]] (January 21–23, 1972) and the [[Conference on Women in the Visual Arts]], at the [[Corcoran School of Art]] in Washington, D.C. (April 20–22, 1972).<ref>{{Cite journal | last = Moravec | first = Michelle | title = Toward a history of feminism, art, and social movements in the United States | journal = [[Frontiers: A Journal of Women Studies]] | volume = 33 | issue = 2 | pages = 22–54 | doi = 10.5250/fronjwomestud.33.2.0022 | date = 2012 | url = https://dx.doi.org/10.5250/fronjwomestud.33.2.0022 | ref = harv | postscript = .}}</ref>
==1970s== {{quote box |quote = For us, there weren't women in the galleries and museums, so we formed our own galleries, we curated our own exhibitions, we formed our own publications, we mentored one another, we even formed schools for [[feminist art]]. We examined the content of the history of art, and we began to make different kinds of art forms based on our experiences as women. So it was both social and something even beyond; in our case, it came back into our own studios.<ref>{{cite web|title=Where Fine Art Meets Craft: The Accessible Works of Joyce Kozloff|url=http://www.aauw.org/2013/08/28/kozloff/|publisher=American Association of University Women|date=August 28, 2013}}</ref> |source = —[[Joyce Kozloff]] |width =30em |border = 0px |bgcolor = LightSteelBlue |quoted = 1 |salign = right }}
The Feminist Art Movement of the 1970s, within the second wave of feminism, "was a major watershed in women's history and the history of art" and "the personal is political" was its slogan.<ref>{{cite book |title=The Power of Feminist Art: The American Movement of the 1970s, History and Impact|year=1996|publisher=Harry N. Abrams, Inc.|location=New York |isbn=9780810926592 |pages=88–103 |author1=Norma Broude |author2=[[Mary D. Garrard]] |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=V21iQgAACAAJ&dq=0-8109-2659-8&hl=en&sa=X&ei=PatYUv3-CILY9QSG8oCgAg&ved=0CEQQ6AEwAQ |deadurl=no |accessdate=11 October 2013}}</ref>
===Key activities===
====''Maintenance Art—Proposal for an Exhibition''==== In 1969 [[Mierle Laderman Ukeles]] wrote a manifesto entitled ''Maintenance Art—Proposal for an Exhibition'', challenging the domestic role of women and proclaiming herself a "maintenance artist". Maintenance, for Ukeles, is the realm of human activities that keep things going, such as cooking, cleaning and child-rearing and her performances in the 1970s included the cleaning of art galleries.<ref>Jon Bird, Michael Newman, ''Rewriting Conceptual Art'', Reaktion Books, 1999, p114-5. {{ISBN|1-86189-052-4}}</ref> Her first performance called ''Touch Sanitation'' was from 1979-80.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://moussemagazine.it/mierle-laderman-ukeles-maintenance-art-queens-museum-new-york/|title=Mierle Laderman Ukeles "Maintenance Art" at Queens Museum, New York •Mousse Magazine|website=moussemagazine.it|language=it-IT|access-date=2018-11-19}}</ref>
====Art Workers' Coalition demands equal representation for women==== A demand for equality in representation for female artists was codified in the [[Art Workers' Coalition]]'s (AWC) Statement of Demands, which was developed in 1969 and published in definitive form in March 1970. The AWC was set up to defend the rights of artists and force museums and galleries to reform their practices. While the coalition sprung up as a protest movement following Greek kinetic sculptor [[Takis|Panagiotis "Takis" Vassilakis]]'s physical removal of his work Tele-Sculpture(1960) from a 1969 exhibition at the [[Museum of Modern Art]], New York, it quickly issued a broad list of demands to 'art museums in general'.
Alongside calls for free admission, better representation of ethnic minorities, late openings and an agreement that galleries would not exhibit an artwork without the artist's consent, the AWC demanded that museums 'encourage female artists to overcome centuries of damage done to the image of the female as an artist by establishing equal representation of the sexes in exhibitions, museum purchases and on selection committees'.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Harrison|first1=Charles|title=Art in theory|date=2000|publisher=Blackwell|location=Oxford [u.a.]|isbn=0-631-16575-4|pages=901–2|edition=Repr.}}</ref>
====Initial feminist art classes==== The first women's art class was taught in the fall of 1970 at Fresno State College, now [[California State University, Fresno]], by artist [[Judy Chicago]]. It became the [[Feminist Art Program]], a full 15-unit program, in the Spring of 1971. This was the first feminist art program in the United States. Fifteen students studied under Chicago at Fresno State College: Dori Atlantis, Susan Boud, Gail Escola, [[Vanalyne Green]], [[Suzanne Lacy]], Cay Lang, [[Karen LeCocq]], Jan Lester, [[Chris Rush]], Judy Schaefer, Henrietta Sparkman, [[Faith Wilding]], Shawnee Wollenman, [[Nancy Youdelman]], and Cheryl Zurilgen. Together, as the Feminist Art Program, these women rented and refurbished an off-campus studio at 1275 Maple Avenue in downtown [[Fresno, California|Fresno]]. Here they collaborated on art, held reading groups, and discussion groups about their life experiences which then influenced their art. Later, Judy Chicago and Miriam Schapiro reestablished the [[Feminist Art Program]] (FAP) at [[California Institute of the Arts]]. After Chicago left for Cal Arts, the class at Fresno State College was continued by Rita Yokoi from 1971 to 1973, and then by [[Joyce Aiken]] in 1973, until her retirement in 1992.{{refn|Aiken opened the all-women's [[co-op]] [[Gallery 25]] with her students, developed the Fresno Art Museum's Council of 100 and the Distinguished Women Artist Series, which helped develop programming and exhibitions about women at the museum.<ref name="Fresno1">{{cite web |author1=Dr. Laura Meyer |author2=Nancy Youdelman | year= | title=A Studio of Their Own: The Legacy of the Fresno Feminist Art Experiment | work=A Studio of their Own | publisher= | url=http://www.astudiooftheirown.org/legacy.html | accessdate=8 January 2011}}</ref>|group=nb}}
The Fresno Feminist Art Program served as a model for other feminist art efforts, such as [[Womanhouse]], a collaborative feminist art exhibition and the first project produced after the Feminist Art Program moved to the [[California Institute of the Arts]] in the fall of 1971. Womanhouse, like the Fresno project, also developed into a feminist studio space and promoted the concept of collaborative women's art.<ref name="Fresno1"/>
The Feminist Studio Workshop was founded in Los Angeles in 1973 by [[Judy Chicago]], [[Arlene Raven]], and [[Sheila Levrant de Bretteville]] as a two-year feminist art program. Women from the program were instrumental in finding and creating the [[Woman's Building]], the first independent center to showcase women's art and culture. Galleries existed there for the entire history of the organization and that was a major venue for exhibiting feminist art.
Art historian [[Arlene Raven]] established the Feminist Art Program in Los Angeles.<ref>{{cite book | author=Arlene Raven | editor=Arlene Raven |editor2=Cassandra L. Langer |editor3=Joanna Frueh |chapter=The Last Essay on Feminist Criticism |title=Feminist Art Criticism: An Anthology|location=New York | publisher=Icon Editions | year=1991 |pages=229–230 | url=https://www.questia.com/read/99908276 |accessdate=8 January 2014 }} via [[Questia]] (subscription required)</ref>
====''Why Have There Been No Great Women Artists?''====
In 1971, the art historian [[Linda Nochlin]] published the article "[[Why Have There Been No Great Women Artists?]]" in ''Woman in Sexist Society,'' which was later reprinted in ''ArtNews,'' where she claimed that there were no "great" women artists at that time, nor in history. By omission, this inferred that artists like [[Georgia O'Keeffe]] and [[Mary Cassatt]] were not considered great. She stated why she felt that there were no great women artists and what organizational and institutional changes needed to take place to create better opportunities for women.<ref>{{cite book | author=Arlene Raven | editor=Arlene Raven |editor2=Cassandra L. Langer |editor3=Joanna Frueh |chapter=The Last Essay on Feminist Criticism |title=Feminist Art Criticism: An Anthology|location=New York | publisher=Icon Editions | year=1991 |pages=41–42 | url=https://www.questia.com/read/99908276 |accessdate=8 January 2014 }} via [[Questia]] (subscription required)</ref>
The author [[Lucy Lippard]] and others identified three tasks to further the understanding and promotion of works by women:<ref>{{cite book | author=Arlene Raven | editor=Arlene Raven |editor2=Cassandra L. Langer |editor3=Joanna Frueh |chapter=The Last Essay on Feminist Criticism |title=Feminist Art Criticism: An Anthology|location=New York | publisher=Icon Editions | year=1991 |page=100 | url=https://www.questia.com/read/99908276 |accessdate=8 January 2014 }} via [[Questia]] (subscription required)</ref> * Find and present current and historic art works by women * Develop a more informal language for writing about art by women * Create theories about the meanings behind women's art and create a history of their works.
====Approaches==== In California, the approach to improve the opportunities for women artists focused on creating venues, such as the [[Woman's Building]] and the Feminist Studio Workshop (FSW), located with the Woman's Building. Gallery spaces, feminist magazine offices, a bookstore, and a cafe were some of the key uses of the Feminist Studio Workshop.<ref name="Art Story" />
Organizations like [[A.I.R. Gallery]] and [[Women Artists in Revolution|Women Artists in Revolution (WAR)]] were formed in New York to provide greater opportunity for female artists and protest for to include works of women artist in art venues that had very few women represented, like [[Whitney Museum]] and the [[Museum of Modern Art]]. In 1970 there was a 23% increase in the number of women artists, and the previous year there was a 10% increase, due to [[Whitney Biennial|Whitney Annual]] (later Whitney Biennial) protests.<ref name="Art Story">{{cite web | url=http://www.theartstory.org/movement-feminist-art.htm# | title=Feminist art movement | publisher=The Art Story Foundation | accessdate=13 January 2014}}</ref>
The [[New York Feminist Art Institute]] opened in June 1979 at 325 Spring Street in the Port Authority Building. The founding members and the initial board of directors were [[Nancy Azara]], [[Miriam Schapiro]], Selena Whitefeather, Lucille Lessane, [[Irene Peslikis]] and Carol Stronghilos.<ref name=Rutgers>Fernanda Perrone, Amy Dawson, and Caroline T. Caviness. [http://www2.scc.rutgers.edu/ead/manuscripts/nyfaif.html Inventory to the Records of the New York Feminist Art Institute, 1976-1990.] Administrative History. Rutgers. July 2009. Retrieved January 15, 2014.</ref> A board of advisers was established of accomplished artists, educators and professional women.<ref name=Rutgers /> For instance, feminist writer and arts editor at ''Ms. Magazine'' Harriet Lyons was an adviser from its start.<ref name="Love2006">Barbara J. Love. ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=kpNarH7t9CkC&pg=PA24 Feminists who Changed America, 1963-1975]''. University of Illinois Press; 2006. {{ISBN|978-0-252-03189-2}}.</ref>
====''Three Weeks in May''==== In 1977, [[Suzanne Lacy]] and collaborator Leslie Labowitz, combined performance art with activism in ''[[Three Weeks in May]]'' on the steps of [[Los Angeles City Hall]]. The performance, which included a map of rapes in the city, and [[self-defense]] classes highlighted [[sexual violence]] against women.<ref name="nytimes">{{Cite news |title=Turning Stereotypes Into Artistic Strengths |author=Karen Rosenberg |newspaper=New York Times |date=March 28, 2008 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/03/28/arts/design/28toge.html }}</ref>
===Organizations and efforts===
{| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! Year !! Title !! Event !! Comments |- | 1969 || [[Women Artists in Revolution]] (WAR) || Protest || Women Artists in Revolution, initially a group within the [[Art Workers' Coalition]], protested the lack of representation of women artists' works in museums in 1969,<ref name="Lippard p. 42">Lippard, Lucy R. ''From the Center: Feminist Essays on Women's Art''. New York: Dutton, 1976. p. 42</ref> and operated only for a few years. Its members formed the Women's Interart Center.<ref name="Ault pp. 27-28" />{{refn|Women Artists in Revolution (WAR) formed to address the under representation of women artist's work in museums. In 1969 the published a list of demands, including "Museums should encourage female artists to overcome the centuries of damage done to the image of the female as an artist by establishing equal representation of the sexes in shows, museum purchases, and on selection committees."<ref name="Ault pp. 27-28">{{cite book|author1=Julie Ault|author2=Social Text Collective|author3=Drawing Center (New York, N.Y.)|title=Alternative Art, New York, 1965-1985: A Cultural Politics Book for the Social Text Collective|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=2ZzxqQqQk94C&pg=PA28|year=2002|publisher=U of Minnesota Press|isbn=978-0-8166-3794-2|pages=27–28}}</ref>|group=nb}} |- | 1970 || Women's Interart Center || Founded || The Women's Interart Center in New York, founded by 1970 in New York City, is still in operation. The Women Artists in Revolution group evolved into the Women's Interart Center, which was a workshop that fostered multidisciplinary approaches, an alternative space and community center - the first of its kind in New York.<ref name="Ault p. 28">{{cite book|author1=Julie Ault|author2=Social Text Collective|author3=Drawing Center (New York, N.Y.)|title=Alternative Art, New York, 1965-1985: A Cultural Politics Book for the Social Text Collective|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=2ZzxqQqQk94C&pg=PA28|year=2002|publisher=U of Minnesota Press|isbn=978-0-8166-3794-2|page=28}}</ref> |- | 1970 || Ad Hoc Women Artists' Committee || Founded || The Ad Hoc Women Artists' Committee (AWC) formed{{refn|Lippard said that the group was founded in 1971.<ref name="Lippard p. 42" />|group=nb}} to address the [[Whitney Museum]]'s exclusion of women artists but expanded its focus over time. Committee members included [[Lucy Lippard]], [[Faith Ringgold]] and others.<ref name="Ault p. 28" /> The Women's Art Registry was created in 1970 to provide information about artists and their works and "counter curatorial bias and ignorance." It was maintained in several locations after the group disbanded in 1971. The registry, a model for other resource initiatives, is now maintained at [[Rutgers University]]'s Mabel Smith Douglass Library.<ref>{{cite book|author1=Julie Ault|author2=Social Text Collective|author3=Drawing Center (New York, N.Y.)|title=Alternative Art, New York, 1965-1985: A Cultural Politics Book for the Social Text Collective|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=2ZzxqQqQk94C&pg=PA28|year=2002|publisher=U of Minnesota Press|isbn=978-0-8166-3794-2|pages=28–29}}</ref> |- | 1971 || Los Angeles Council of Women Artists || Protest || In response to the 1971 ''[[Art and Technology exhibition]]'' at the [[Los Angeles County Museum of Art]] (LACMA), an ad hoc group of women organized, calling themselves the Los Angeles Council of Women Artists. They researched the number of women included in exhibitions at LACMA and issued a June 15, 1971 report, in which they protested sexual inequality in the artworld and that lack of art works from women at the museum's "Art and Technology" exhibition.<ref>{{cite book|title=Female Artists, Past and Present|year=1974|publisher=Women's History Research Center.|page=11}}</ref><ref name="LACWA Getty">{{cite web | url=http://www.getty.edu/pacificstandardtime/explore-the-era/archives/i143 | title=Los Angeles Council of Women Artists Report | publisher=Getty Center | date=June 15, 1971 | accessdate=12 January 2014}}</ref> They set a precedent for the [[Guerrilla Girls]] and other feminist groups.<ref name="LACWA Getty" /> |- | 1971<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.amherst.edu/system/files/media/0115/Butler_Abundant_Evidence_Black_Women_Art.PDF | title=Abundant Evidence: Black Women Artists of the 1960s and 1970s | publisher=Amherst College | accessdate=12 January 2014}}</ref> ||[[Where We At (WWA)]]<ref name="Mark" /> || Founded || Women artists of color also began organizing, founding groups such as the African American group [[Where We At (WWA)]] and the Chicana group Las Mujeres Muralistas in order to gain visibility for artists who had been excluded or marginalized on the basis of both their sex and racial or ethnic identity.<ref name="Mark">{{cite book|last=Mark|first=Lisa Gabrielle|title=WACK! Art and the Feminist Revolution|year=2008|publisher=Museum of Contemporary Art Los Angeles|location=Los Angeles}}</ref><ref name="Burgess Fuller">{{cite book|last=Burgess Fuller|first=Diana|title=Art/Women/California|year=2002|publisher=University of California Press|location=Berkeley}}</ref> |- | 1972 || [[A.I.R. Gallery]] || Founded || A collective gallery formed in New York and remains in operation.<ref name="Lippard p. 42" />{{refn|Collective galleries such as [[A.I.R. Gallery]] in New York (1972–present) and Artemesia in [[Chicago]] were formed to provide visibility for art by feminist artists. The strength of the feminist movement allowed for the emergence and visibility of many new types of work by women but also helped facilitate a range of new practices by men.<ref name="Lippard p. 42" />|group=nb|name="A.I.R. and Artemesia"}}<ref>Meredith A.Brown 'The Balance Sheet: A.I.R. Gallery and Government Funding' ''n.paradoxa: international feminist art journal'' vol. 27 (Jan 2011) pp.29-37</ref> |- | 1972 ||[[Women's Caucus for Art]] || Founded || [[Women's Caucus for Art]], an offshoot of the College Art Association was founded in 1972 at the San Francisco Conference. A WCA conference is held annually and there are chapters in most areas of the U.S.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.nationalwca.org/LAA/LTA2012.pdf | title=40th Anniversary Celebration | publisher=National Women's Caucus for Art | year=2012 | accessdate=12 January 2014 | pages=2}}</ref> |- | 1972<ref>{{cite book|author=Alexandra Juhasz|title=Women of Vision: Histories in Feminist Film and Video|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=QOMn0tRfF-AC&pg=PA15|year=2001|publisher=University of Minnesota Press|isbn=978-0-8166-3371-5|pages=15–16}}</ref> || Women's Video Festival || Held festivals || The Women's Video Festival was held yearly for a number of years in New York City.<ref name="DowningDowning2011">{{cite book|author1=John D. H. Downing|author2=John Derek Hall Downing|title=Encyclopedia of Social Movement Media|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=iwPX23VameIC&pg=PA198|year=2011|publisher=SAGE Publications|isbn=978-0-7619-2688-7|page=198}}</ref> Many women artists continue to organize working groups, collectives, and nonprofit galleries in various locales around the world.{{citation needed|date=January 2014}} |- | 1973 || Washington Women's Arts Center || Founded || Washington, DC, an artist-run inter-arts center opened with exhibits, writing workshops, a newsletter and quarterly literary journal Womansphere, as well as business workshops, lectures including Kathryn Anne Porter's final public lecture. The center operated through 1991. Founders included artists Barbara Frank, Janis Goodman, Kathryn Butler, and Sarah Hyde, writer Ann Slayton Leffler and art historian Josephine Withers. |- | 1973 || The [[Woman's Building]] || Founded|| Los Angeles, CA was the first independent center for women's culture. It included the Feminist Studio Workshop was founded by [[Sheila Levrant de Bretteville]], art historian [[Arlene Raven]], and [[Judy Chicago]] in 1973.<ref name="Fresno1"/><ref>Lippard, Lucy R. ''From the Center: Feminist Essays on Women's Art''. New York: Dutton, 1976. p. 84</ref> {{refn|Many of the feminist artists and designers from CalArts joined other feminist artists at the Woman's Building, an important center of the west coast feminist artist movement in the 1970s and 1980s in which meetings, workshops, performances, and exhibitions regularly took place. Womanspace Gallery relocated there. During the first year, there were national conferences on feminist film, writing, ceramics, among others.{{citation needed|date=January 2014}}|group=nb}} It closed in 1991. |- | 1973 || Womanspace || Founded || Womanspace was an artist‐run gallery opened to the public on January 27, 1973, in a converted laundromat in Los Angeles. It resulted from the energy and ideas made tangible by the work of the Los Angeles Council of Women Artists, [[Womanhouse]], the West Coast Women Artists conference, and other feminist actions happening throughout the city. According to the first issue of ''Womanspace Journal'' (February/March 1973), the founders included Lucy Adelman, Miki Benoff, Sherry Brody, [[Carole Caroompas]], [[Judy Chicago]], Max Cole, Judith Fried, Gretchen Glicksman (director of Womanspace), Elyse Grinstein, Linda Levi, Joan Logue, Mildred Monteverdi, Beverly O'Neill, Fran Raboff, [[Rachel Rosenthal]], [[Betye Saar]], [[Miriam Schapiro]], Wanda Westcoast, [[Faith Wilding]], and Connie Zehr. Womanspace moved to the Woman's Building later in 1973, and closed in 1974.<ref>{{cite web|title=Checklist of the WB Exhibition|url=http://www.otis.edu/sites/default/files/WB_Checklist_Final_012312.pdf|year=2012|publisher=Otis College of Art and Design}}</ref> |- | 1973 || Artemesia || Founded || A collective gallery formed in Chicago.<ref name="Lippard p. 42" /><ref>{{cite book|author1=Nancy A. Naples|author2=Karen Bojar|title=Teaching Feminist Activism: Strategies from the Field|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ZYVEAgAAQBAJ&pg=PA99|date=2 December 2013|publisher=Routledge|isbn=978-1-317-79499-8|page=99}}</ref>{{refn||group=nb|name="A.I.R. and Artemesia"}} |- | 1973<ref>{{cite book|author=Karen Mary Davalos|title=Exhibiting Mestizaje: Mexican (American) Museums in the Diaspora|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=O8UK3VkkHVsC&pg=PA63|year=2001|publisher=UNM Press|isbn=978-0-8263-1900-5|page=63}}</ref> || [[Mujeres Muralistas|Las Mujeres Muralistas]]<ref name="Mark" /> || Founded || Women artists of color also began organizing, founding groups such as the African American group [[Where We At (WWA)]] and the Chicana group L[[Mujeres Muralistas|as Mujeres Muralistas]] in order to gain visibility for artists who had been excluded or marginalized on the basis of both their sex and racial or ethnic identity.<ref name="Mark" /><ref name="Burgess Fuller" /> |- | 1973 || [[Women's Art Registry of Minnesota]] || Founded || WARM started as a women's art collective in 1973 and ran the WARM Gallery in Minneapolis from 1976 to 1991.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Gardner-Huggett|first1=Joanna|title=Review: WARM: A Feminist Art Collective in Minnesota by Joanna Inglot|journal=Woman's Art Journal|date=2008|volume=29|issue=1|pages=64–66|jstor=20358154}}</ref> |- |1974 |[[Women's Studio Workshop]] |Founded |Women's Studio Workshop (WSW) was founded in 1974 by Ann Kalmbach, [[Tatana Kellner]], Anita Wetzel, and Barbara Leoff Burge as an alternative space for women artists to create new work, gain artistic experience, and develop new skills. To this day, WSW still operates artist residencies and internships for women-identified artists, in addition to public arts projects, educational programming for emerging and established artists, and much more. |- | 1975 || [[Spiderwoman Theater]] || Founded || The theater was created to tell stories from an urban perspective. It is named after the [[Spider Grandmother|Hopi goddess of creation]] whose objective is to "assist humans in maintaining balance in all things."<ref name="McAdamsHobson2012">{{cite book|author1=Janet McAdams|author2=Geary Hobson|author3=Kathryn Walkiewicz|title=The People Who Stayed: Southeastern Indian Writing After Removal|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Hdw27w1rbywC&pg=PA47|date=9 October 2012|publisher=University of Oklahoma Press|isbn=978-0-8061-8575-0|page=47}}</ref> |- | 1979 || [[New York Feminist Art Institute]] || Founded || Founding members: [[Nancy Azara]], Lucille Lessane, [[Miriam Schapiro]], [[Irene Peslikis]] <ref>Katie Cercone 'The New York Feminist Art Institute' ''n.paradoxa: international feminist art journal'' vol. 22 (July 2008) pp.49-56 [http://www.nyfai.org/ New York Feminist Art Institute]</ref> |- | 1985 || The Woman's Salon for Literature in New York || Founded || Founded by [[Gloria Feman Orenstein]].<ref>{{cite web|title=GLORIA ORENSTEIN - Professor of Comparative Literature and Gender Studies, FOUNDER OF THE WOMAN'S SALON FOR LITERATURE|url=http://www.veteranfeministsofamerica.org/legacy/Gloria%20Orenstein.htm|website=Veteran Feminists of America|publisher=Veteran Feminists of America|accessdate=27 February 2018}}</ref> it lasted for more than 10 years and hosted such important artists as [[Judy Chicago]] and [[Kate Millett]]. |}
===Publications=== ''[[The Feminist Art Journal]]'' was a feminist art publication that was produced from 1972 to 1977, and was the first stable, widely read journal of its kind. Beginning in 1975 there were scholarly publications about feminism, feminist art and historic women's art, most notably ''Through the Flower: My Struggle as a Woman Artist'' by [[Judy Chicago]]; and ''Against Our Will: Men, Women and Rape'' (1975) by [[Susan Brownmiller]]; ''Woman Artists: 1550-1950'' (1976) about [[Linda Nochlin]] and Ann Sutherland Harris's exhibition; ''From the Center: Feminist Essays in Women's Art'' (1976) by [[Lucy Lippard]]; ''Of Woman Born,'' by [[Adrienne Rich]], ''When God Was a Woman'' (1976) by [[Merlin Stone]]; ''By Our Own Hands'' (1978) by [[Faith Wilding]]; ''Gyn/Ecology'' (1978) by [[Mary Daly]]; and ''Woman and Nature'' by [[Susan Griffin]].<ref name="Visions and Re-visions">{{cite book | author=Moira Roth | chapter=Visions and Re-Visions: Rosa Luxemburg and the Artist's Mother |title=Feminist Art Criticism: An Anthology |editor=Arlene Raven |editor2=Cassandra L. Langer |editor3=Joanna Frueh |location=New York | publisher=Icon Editions | year=1991 |page=109 | url=https://www.questia.com/read/99908276 |accessdate=8 January 2014 }} via [[Questia]] (subscription required)</ref>
In 1977, both ''[[Chrysalis (magazine)|Chrysalis]]'' and ''[[Heresies: A Feminist Publication on Art and Politics]]'' began publication.<ref name="Visions and Re-visions" /><ref>[http://helios.hampshire.edu/nomorenicegirls/heretics/#index ''Heresies: A Feminist Publication on Art and Politics''](1977–92), now the subject of a documentary film, [http://helios.hampshire.edu/nomorenicegirls/heretics/#overview The Heretics].</ref>{{refn|''Chrysalis Magazine'' (1977–80), was organized out of the Los Angeles [[Woman's Building]].{{citation needed|date=January 2014}}|group=nb}}
==1980s== Feminist art evolved during the 1980s, with a trend away from experiential works and social causes. Instead, there was a trend toward works based upon [[Postmodern theory]] and influenced by [[psychoanalysis]]. Inequal representation in the artworld was a continuing issue.<ref name="Art Story" />
===Key activities===
====Guerrilla Girls==== [[Guerrilla Girls]] was formed by 7 women artists in the spring of 1985 in response to the [[Museum of Modern Art]]'s exhibition "An International Survey of Recent Painting and Sculpture", which opened in 1984. The exhibition was the inaugural show in the MoMA's newly renovated and expanded building, and was planned to be a survey of the most important contemporary artists.<ref>{{cite news|last=Brenson|first=Michael|title=A Living Artists Show at the Modern Museum|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1984/04/21/arts/a-living-artists-show-at-the-modern-museum.html?pagewanted=all|accessdate=27 February 2013|newspaper=The New York Times|date=April 21, 1984}}</ref>
The Guerrilla Girls have researched sexism and created artworks at the request of various people and institutions, among others, the [[Istanbul Modern]], Istanbul, Witte de With Center for Contemporary Arts, Rotterdam and Fundación Bilbao Arte Fundazioa, Bilbao. They have also partnered with [[Amnesty International]], contributing pieces to a show under the organization's "Protect the Human" initiative.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.amnesty.org.uk/news_details.asp?NewsID=16632 |title=Press Releases | Amnesty International UK |publisher=Amnesty.org.uk |date= |accessdate=2015-03-10}}</ref>
====Mass communication==== [[Mass communication]] is "the process by which a person, group of people, or large organization creates a message and transmits it through some type of medium to a large, anonymous, heterogeneous audience." <ref>{{cite book|title=Media and Mass Communication Theories|date=2009|publisher=SAGE Publications|pages=624–628|last1=Pearce|first1=K.J.}}</ref> Women such as [[Barbara Kruger]] and [[Jenny Holzer]] used forms of graphic mass communication such as refined slogans and graphics to increase awareness of the inequity faced by women artists.<ref name="Art Story" />
'''Kiki Smith'''
During the 1970s [[Kiki Smith]] was one of the many artists involved in the collaborative projects. As the art scene became more politicized in the 1980s, Kiki Smith's art work also became more political as well. Her work started "involving issues like abortion, race and AIDS." <ref>https://www.nytimes.com/1992/08/16/arts/art-view-kiki-smith-the-body-as-political-battleground.html</ref> When asked if she considered herself a feminist artist, Smith responded:
<blockquote>Yes, I would say that generationally I am, and I would say that without the feminist movement I wouldn't exist; and an enormous amount of the artwork that we take for granted wouldn't exist; and a lot of the subject matter that we assume can be encompassed by art wouldn't exist. The feminist movement exponentially expanded what art is, and how we look at art, and who is considered to be included in the discourse of art-making. I think that it caused a tremendous, radical change. You don't want to have a cultural notion that one specific gender embodies creativity. All humanity – and all aspects of gender and sexuality and how people define themselves – are inherently creative. It's against the interests of the culture at large not to embrace feminism as a model, just like many other models of liberation, because they don't only liberate women, they liberate everybody.<ref>http://www.askyfilledwithshootingstars.com/wordpress/?p=1128</ref></blockquote>
==== Sister Serpents ==== [[Sister Serpents]] was a radical [[Feminism|feminist]] art collective that began as a small group women in Chicago in the summer of 1989, as a direct response to the [[Webster v. Reproductive Health Services]] Supreme Court decision.<ref>{{Cite news|url=|title=SisterSerpents: A Radical Feminist Art Collective|last=Margolin|first=Victor|date=1992|work=AIGA Journal of Graphic Design|access-date=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|issue=2|volume=10}}</ref> Their goal as a collective was to empower women and to increase awareness of women's issues through radical art,<ref>{{Cite news|url=|title=Hissing with anger: SisterSerpents exhibit art|last=George|first=Erika|date=March 12, 1991|work=The Chicago Maroon|access-date=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}}</ref> and to use art as a weapon to battle misogyny.<ref>{{Cite news|url=|title=Serpentine artists hiss at misogyny|last=Bradley|first=Amanda|date=February 26, 1991|work=The Daily Northwestern|access-date=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}}</ref>
===Publications=== *''[[Feminist Art Journal]]'' * ''Genders: Feminist Art and (Post)Modern Anxieties''<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.genders.org/g32/g32_bailey.html |title=''Genders: Feminist Art and (Post)Modern Anxieties'' |publisher=Genders.org |date= |accessdate=2014-01-12 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130512234951/http://www.genders.org/g32/g32_bailey.html |archivedate=2013-05-12 |df= }}</ref> * ''[[M/E/A/N/I/N/G]]'' had 20 issues (1986-1996)<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://jacket2.org/reissues/meaning|title = M/E/A/N/I/N/G, 1986-1996 (ed. Susan Bee and Mira Schor) {{!}} Jacket2|website = jacket2.org|access-date = 2016-03-05}}</ref> and 5 on-line issues (2002-2011)<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.writing.upenn.edu/pepc/meaning/ |title=M/E/A/N/I/N/G, ed. Susan Bee and Mira Schor |publisher=Writing.upenn.edu |date= |accessdate=2014-01-12}}</ref> * ''Woman's Art Journal'' (1980–present)<ref>{{cite web|url=http://womansartjournal.org/27-2.php#ABOUT |title=''Woman's Art Journal'' |publisher=Womansartjournal.org |date= |accessdate=2014-01-12}}</ref> *''Heresies''<ref>{{cite web|url=http://heresiesfilmproject.org/ |title=THE HERETICS : Directed by Joan Braderman, Produced by Crescent Diamond |publisher=Heresiesfilmproject.org |date= |accessdate=2015-03-10}}</ref> *''LTTR''<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lttr.org/ |title=LTTR |publisher=LTTR |date= |accessdate=2015-03-10}}</ref> *''Meridians''<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.smith.edu/meridians/ |title=Meridians: feminism, race, transnationalism |publisher=Smith.edu |date= |accessdate=2015-03-10}}</ref> *''The Journal of Women and Performance''<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.womenandperformance.org/archive.html |title=Issues | Women & Performance |publisher=Womenandperformance.org |date= |accessdate=2015-03-10}}</ref>
==1990s==
===Key activities===
====''Bad Girls''==== ''Bad Girls (Part I) and Bad Girls (Part II)'' were a 1994 pair of exhibitions at New Museum in New York, curated by [[Marcia Tucker]]. A companion exhibition, ''Bad Girls West'' was curated by Marcia Tanner and exhibited at [[UCLA|UCLA's]] Wright Gallery the same year.<ref>{{cite web|title=Bad Girls (Part I)|url=http://archive.newmuseum.org/index.php/Detail/Occurrence/Show/occurrence_id/235|website=The New Museum Digital Archive|publisher=The New Museum|accessdate=21 September 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Smith|first1=Roberta|title=Review/Art; A Raucous Caucus Of Feminists Being Bad|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1994/01/21/arts/review-art-a-raucous-caucus-of-feminists-being-bad.html?pagewanted=all|accessdate=21 September 2016|publisher=New York Times|date=January 21, 1994}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Knight|first1=Christopher|title=ART REVIEW : 'Bad Girls': Feminism on Wry : Tone Bemusedly Subversive in West Coast Edition of N.Y. Show|url=http://articles.latimes.com/1994-02-08/entertainment/ca-20290_1_bad-girls-west|accessdate=21 September 2016|publisher=Los Angeles Times|date=February 8, 1994|language=English}}</ref>
====''Sexual Politics: Judy Chicago's The Dinner Party in Feminist Art History''====
''Sexual Politics: Judy Chicago's The Dinner Party in Feminist Art History'', a 1996 exhibition and text curated and written by [[Amelia Jones]], re-exhibited [[Judy Chicago|Judy Chicago's]] ''[[The Dinner Party]]'' for the first time since 1988. It was presented by the UCLA Armand [[Hammer Museum]].<ref>{{cite web|last1=Reilly|first1=Maura|title=The Dinner Party: Tour and Home|url=https://www.brooklynmuseum.org/eascfa/dinner_party/tour_and_home/|website=Brooklyn Museum|accessdate=21 September 2016}}</ref>
'''''Riot Grrrl'''''
The [[Riot grrrl]] movement was focused mostly on music, but the [[DIY]] aspect of this scene included feminist knowledge in forms of underground [[zines]], which included poems, articles, comics, etc.
===Publications=== *''[[n.paradoxa]]'' (1998–present)<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ktpress.co.uk/ |title=Official home page for n.paradoxa: international feminist art journal; feminist art; contemporary women artists; feminist art theory; feminist artists; writing about women artists; KT press | issn=1461-0434 |publisher=Ktpress.co.uk |date= |accessdate=2015-03-10}}</ref>
==2000s==
===Key activities===
====''WACK! Art and the Feminist Revolution''==== The 2007 exhibition, ''[[WACK! Art and the Feminist Revolution]]'', focused on the feminist art movement. It was organized by the [[Museum of Contemporary Art, Los Angeles]] and traveled to [[PS1 Contemporary Art Center]] in New York. WACK! featured by 120 artists from 21 countries, covering the period of 1965-1980.<ref>{{cite web|title=WACK!: Art and the Feminist Revolution|url=http://www.moca.org/exhibition/wack-art-and-the-feminist-revolution|website=MOCA|accessdate=21 September 2016}}</ref>
====''A Studio of Their Own''==== ''A Studio of Their Own: The Legacy of the Fresno Feminist Experiment'' was performed on the [[California State University, Fresno]] campus at the Phebe Conley Art Gallery in 2009. It was a retrospective that paid homage to the women from the 1970s who were part of the first women's art program.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fresnostatenews.com/archive/2009/08/feministart.htm |title=Feminist art retrospective opens Aug. 26 |date=August 11, 2009 |accessdate=13 January 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140113182414/http://www.fresnostatenews.com/archive/2009/08/feministart.htm |archivedate=13 January 2014 |df= }}</ref>
====The Feminist Art Project==== The Feminist Art Project website and information portal was founded at [[Rutgers University]] in 2006. A resource for artists and scholars in the United States, it publishes a calendar of events and runs conferences, discussions and education projects. It describes itself as "a strategic intervention against the ongoing erasure of women from the cultural record".<ref>[http://feministartproject.rutgers.edu/ The Feminist Art Project]. Rutgers University. Retrieved February 4, 2014.</ref>
===Feminist art curatorial practices===
====History====
Feminist art curating practices are within a museumism genre, which is a deconstructing of the museum space by curator/artist where the museum looks at itself or the artist/curator looks at the museum.
"If artists as curators of their own exhibition is no longer uncommon, neither is the artist-created museum or collection ... These artists use museological practices to confront the ways in which museums rewrite history through the politics of collecting and presentation ... However, their work often inadvertently reasserts the validity of the museum" (Corrin, 1994, p. 5).<ref>CORRIN, L. G. (1993). Mining the museum: An installation confronting history. [[Curator: The Museum Journal]], 36(4), 302-313. doi:10.1111/j.2151-6952.1993.tb00804.x</ref><ref>Klebesadel, Helen (2005). Reframing studio art production and critique. In Janet Marstine (Ed.), New museum theory and practice an introduction (pp. 247-265). Malden, MA: Wiley-Blackwell.</ref>
[[Katy Deepwell]] documents feminist curating practice and feminist art history with a theoretical foundation that feminist curating is not biologically determinate.<ref>Deepwell, Katy (2005). Feminist curatorial strategies and practices since the 1970s. In Janet Marstine (Ed.), New museum theory and practice an introduction (pp. 64-84). Malden, MA: Wiley-Blackwell.</ref>
====Characteristics====
Feminist art curatorial practices are collaborative and reject the notion of an artist as an individual creative genius.<ref>Parker, R., & Pollock, G. (1981). Old mistresses: Women, art and ideology. New York: Pantheon Books.</ref><ref>Curatorial Collectives and Feminist Politics in 21st Century Europe: An Interview with Kuratorisk Aktion</ref><ref>Hedlin Hayden, Malin & Sjoholm Skrubbe, Jessica (Eds.). (2010). Feminisms is still our name: Seven essays on historiography and curatorial practices. Cambridge: Cambridge Scholars Publishing.</ref>
====Examples====
* The ''Out of Here'' exhibition<ref>[http://judychicago.arted.psu.edu/out-of-here/exhibition/ ''Out of Here'']. Judy Chicago site. Retrieved March 7, 2015.</ref> is an example of feminist art curatorial practice. * [[Womanhouse]] * ''Teatro Chicana: A Collective Memoir and Selected Plays'' highlights [[El Movimiento]] and Chicana women's civil rights movements representing their varied communities and histories.<ref>Garcia, L. E., Gutierrez, S. M., & Nuñez, F. (2008). Teatro chicana: A collective memoir and selected plays. Austin: University of Texas Press.</ref>
==2010s==
===Key activities=== '''!Women Art Revolution'''
The documentary film ''[[!Women Art Revolution]]'' was played at New York's [[IFC Center]] beginning June 1, 2011, before opening around the country.<ref>{{cite web|last=Yerman |first=Marcia G. |url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/marcia-g-yerman/women-art-revolution-at-m_b_835434.html |title=!Women Art Revolution at MoMA |publisher=Huffington Post |date=March 14, 2011 |accessdate=November 7, 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Voynar |first=Kim |url=http://moviecitynews.com/2011/06/review-women-art-revolution/ |title=Review: !Women Art Revolution |publisher=Movie City News |date=June 1, 2011 |accessdate=November 7, 2011}}</ref>
'''Woman's Building'''
The Los Angeles [[Woman's Building]] was the subject of a major exhibition in 2012 at the [[Ben Maltz Gallery]] at [[Otis College of Art and Design]] called [http://www.otis.edu/ben-maltz-gallery/womans-building Doin' It in Public, Feminism and Art at the Woman's Building]. It included oral histories on video, emphemera, and artists' projects. It was part of the [[J. Paul Getty Trust|Getty]] initiative [[Pacific Standard Time: Art in L.A., 1945-1980|Pacific Standard Time]].
'''Stop Telling Women To Smile'''
[http://stoptellingwomentosmile.com/ Stop Telling Women To Smile] was an ongoing, traveling series that started in Fall of 2012. Artist [[Tatyana Fazlalizadeh]], started this project in Brooklyn, NYC, but had also been in Chicago, Paris, and Mexico City. Street art such as STWTS is a modern way of mass communication art.
'''"Gallery Tally"'''
In 2013, [[Micol Hebron|Michol Hebron]] started the "Gallery Tally" project, where Hebron had different galleries across Los Angeles and New York make posters showing the uneven representation in the art world. She found that about 70% of artists represented in these two cities are men.<ref name="latimes.com">http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/arts/miranda/la-et-cam-artist-micol-hebron-gender-artforum-covers-20150410-column.html</ref> Hebron has extended this project outside of L.A., and now continues the project all over the states, with updates to her [http://gallerytally.tumblr.com/ blog].In 2015, Hebron went through every cover published from [https://www.artforum.com/ Artforum]. Since 1962, there have been 526 different monthly covers. Hebron found only 18% feature art by women, and male artists made 74% of the covers.<ref name="latimes.com"/>
'''"Guarded"'''
"Guarded" was a photography project by artist [http://www.tayloryo.com/ Taylor Yocom] in 2015 for which Yocom photographed students from University of Iowa, showing what these women carried with them when they had to walk alone at night.<ref>http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2015/05/06/weapons-women-carry-to-fend-off-attackers-taylor-yocom_n_7222220.html</ref>
'''Now Be Here'''
[http://www.nowbeherela.com/ Now Be Here] was a project from August 28, 2016, where 733 female and female identifying women came together in Los Angeles to be photographed together to show solidarity.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://artandcakela.com/2016/08/29/now-be-here-women-artists-make-a-stand-and-a-photo/|title=Now Be Here: Women artists make a stand, and a photo|date=2016-08-29|website=ART AND CAKE|access-date=2016-09-26}}</ref> The project continued with Now Be Here #2 at the Brooklyn Museum on October 23, 2016,<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://news.artnet.com/art-world/600-female-artists-brooklyn-museum-719489|title=600 Female Artists Took this Selfie at the Brooklyn Museum {{!}} artnet News|date=2016-10-26|newspaper=artnet News|access-date=2017-02-23|language=en-US}}</ref> and Now Be Here #3 at the Pérez Art Museum Miami (PAMM) on December 10, 2016.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://miamigirls.org/events/now-be-here-miami/|title=Now Be Here #3 gathers Miami female artists at Perez Art Museum|date=2016-12-26|newspaper=Miami Girls Foundation|access-date=2017-02-23|language=en-US}}</ref>
'''The Future is Female'''
[https://hyperallergic.com/381561/the-future-is-female-21c-museum-hotel-kentucky-2017/ The Future is Female] art exhibit located within the 21C Museum and Hotel in Louisville, Kentucky opened its doors just following our most recent presidential election and features feminist art works that operate to epitomize the experience of womanhood while simultaneously addressing larger global issues. The exhibit highlights the artwork of handful of feminist artists including [[Vibha Galhotra]], [[Alison Saar]], [[Carrie Mae Weems]], [[Michele Pred]], [[Frances Goodman]], [[Kiki Smith]], and [[Sanell Aggenbach]] who emerged in the wake of the second wave Feminist Arts Movement.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://hyperallergic.com/381561/the-future-is-female-21c-museum-hotel-kentucky-2017/|title=The Future Is (Still) Female: Feminist Art for the 21st Century|date=2017-05-27|work=Hyperallergic|access-date=2018-04-13|language=en-US}}</ref>
'''Women's Invitational Exhibition 2017'''
The ''Women's Invitational Exhibition'' is an art exhibit that features the works from minority women artists. The entire gallery showcases only a select few artists. However, each individual woman shows multitude of different topics via a variety of mediums.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://islamicartrevival.com/?page_id=1777|title=Women’s Invitational Exhibition 2017 {{!}} Islamic Art Revival Series|website=islamicartrevival.com|language=en-US|access-date=2018-04-13}}</ref>
'''Hands On'''
''HANDS ON'' is collection of works by Karen Lederer made in 2017. Works within the collection date from 2015 to 2017. The art was made in response to political debates about women.
<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.fieldprojectsgallery.com/show-40-karen-lederer|title=Show #40 Karen Lederer|website=Field Projects|language=en-US|access-date=2018-04-13}}</ref>
== Feminist Art Movement in 2018 ==
=== #metoo movement represented in Feminist Art Movement === Carnegie Mellon art galleries director Elizabeth Chodos and assistant director Margaret Cox put up a gallery for Faith Wilding's artwork, who was a prominent artist who studied art in the 70's when issues like rape and sexual abuse were too taboo to discuss. She learned to be open with her artwork focusing on female bodies working alongside other female art students. She did however, criticize the fact that most art teachers were male. The ideas explored in her work offered influence for key elements of the #metoo movement but also recognizes that we still have a long way to go in terms of equality and respect. Wilding's artwork addressed social issues relating to sexual assault that are just now beginning to emerge culturally through #metoo.

revision.text:
{{Infobox NRHP | name = Fort Walton Mound | nrhp_type = nhl | image = FortWaltonBeachTempleMound3.jpg | caption = Fort Walton Mound, in the Indian Temple Mound and Museum | location = [[Fort Walton Beach, Florida|Fort Walton Beach]], [[Florida]], [[United States|USA]] | coordinates = {{coord|30|24|15.948|N|86|36|26.352|W|display=inline,title}} | locmapin = Florida#USA | area = | architect = | architecture = | built = | designated_nrhp_type = July 19, 1964<ref name=nhl>[http://tps.cr.nps.gov/nhl/detail.cfm?ResourceId=166&ResourceType=Site Fort Walton Mound] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090502192256/http://tps.cr.nps.gov/nhl/detail.cfm?ResourceId=166&ResourceType=Site |date=2009-05-02 }} at [http://tps.cr.nps.gov/nhl National Historic Landmarks Program] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070927042842/http://tps.cr.nps.gov/nhl |date=September 27, 2007 }}</ref> | added = October 15, 1966 | refnum = 66000268<ref name=nrhp>{{cite web|url=http://www.nationalregisterofhistoricplaces.com/FL/Okaloosa/state.html|title=National Register of Historical Places - Florida (FL), Okaloosa County|date=2007-02-14|work=National Register of Historic Places|publisher=National Park Service}}</ref> | visitation_num = | visitation_year = | governing_body = }} The '''Fort Walton Mound''' ([[Smithsonian trinomial|8OK6]]) is an [[archaeological site]] located in present-day [[Fort Walton Beach, Florida]], [[United States]]. The large [[platform mound]] was built about 850 [[Common Era|CE]] by the [[Pensacola culture]], a local form of the [[Mississippian culture]].<ref name=GIBBON>{{cite encyclopedia|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=_0u2y_SVnmoC&pg=PA293&dq=Fort+Walton+Site+and+Culture+gibbon&hl=en&sa=X&ei=U8WLT8KWIob22gXD_uHQCQ&ved=0CDoQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q&f=false|encyclopedia=Archaeology of Prehistoric Native America: An Encyclopedia|editor1= By Guy E. Gibbon|editor2= Kenneth M. Ames|title=Fort Walton Site and Culture|page=293}}</ref> Because of its significance, the mound was designated a [[National Historic Landmark]] in 1964.
Still reduced by time, the massive mound is still {{convert|12|ft|m}} high and {{convert|223|ft|m}} wide at the base. It was an expression of a complex culture, built by a hierarchical society whose leaders planned and organized the labor of many workers for such construction. The mound served combined ceremonial, political and religious purposes. At the center of the village and its supporting agricultural lands, the mound served as the platform for the temple and residence of the [[tribal chief|chief]]. Successive leaders were buried in the mound and additional layers were added over time.
This is one of three surviving mound complexes in the panhandle, the others being [[Letchworth Mounds]] and [[Lake Jackson Mounds Archaeological State Park|Lake Jackson Mounds]] state parks.
==History== The Fort Walton Mound was probably built around 800 AD, although [[Charles H. Fairbanks]] who excavated the mound in 1960 believed it was built between 1500 and 1650 based on pottery sherds he uncovered and analyzed.<ref>Fairbanks, Charles, "Excavations at the Fort Walton Temple Mound, 1960," Florida Anthropologist, Vol. XVIII, No. 4, December 1965, pg. 243.</ref> The mound served as the ceremonial and political center of their chiefdom and probably the residence of the chief. It was also the burial ground of the elites in the society. Archaeological evidence suggests that several buildings once stood on top of the mound, perhaps at different times throughout its use. These buildings were probably done in the typical [[wattle and daub]] construction common among Southeastern Native American groups. By sometime in the late 1600s the mound was abandoned by its original builders and lay dormant in use until the area was reinhabited by white settlers in the mid 19th century.
The Confederate soldiers established "Camp Walton" at the base of Fort Walton Mound in 1861 during the Civil War to guard Santa Rosa Sound and Choctawhatchee Bay. As with many of Florida's mound structures, the Fort Walton Mound was first excavated by antiquarians and amateur archaeologists. The Walton Guard soldiers are the first recorded group to have excavated the mound. John Love McKinnon, an officer with the Walton Guards at the time, wrote a description of their excavation in his book "History of Walton County."<ref name="McKinnon">McKinnon, John, "History of Walton County," pg. 68.</ref> McKinnon noted that several human remains the soldiers unearthed were from large individuals and probably belonged to warriors as indicated by damage they observed on the skulls, thighs and arms bones consistent with hacking and blunt force trauma. He speculated that the area they dug into was once a [[charnel house]].<ref name="McKinnon"/> A couple decades after the Civil War, in 1883 S.T. Walker wrote a report about excavating the mound for the Smithsonian Institution.<ref name="Walker">Walker, S.T., "Annual report of the Smithsonian Institution for the year 1883".</ref>{{rp|854}} Walker surveyed several mounds in the Florida Panhandle and noted that many curiosity seekers had dug into the mound over the years. Walker noted that Dr. S.S. Forbes from [[Milton, Florida]], had excavated the mound previously and discovered bones and several clay effigies which he later donated to the Smithsonian.<ref name="Walker"/>{{rp|862}}
[[Clarence Bloomfield Moore]] also excavated the mound in 1901 and brought many before unseen ceramic vessels and burial items to light.<ref>Brose, David and Nancy White, "The Northwest Florida Expedition of Clarence Bloomfield Moore," University of Alabama Press, 1999, pgs. 61-81.</ref> In 1940 the highly respected archaeologist Gordon Willey and Richard Woodbury rexamined the Fort Walton Mound and other sites Moore had visited.<ref>http://140.247.102.177/Willey/grw.html#June6</ref> Their work here was mentioned in Willey's highly acclaimed work "Archaeology of the Florida Gulf Coast," which he completed when he worked for the Bureau of American Ethnology Smithsonian Institution.<ref>Willey, Gordon, "Archaeology of the Florida Gulf Coast," Washington, Smithsonian Institution, 1949, pg. 213-214</ref> By 1960 Dr. Charles Fairbanks, an archaeologist and professor at Florida State University, was contacted by the city and he excavated the mound to determine the original size, shape, and construction method of the mound.<ref>{{cite journal |title= |author= |journal= |jstor=25615551}}</ref> Throughout the 1960s and 1970s the Fort Walton Mound was excavated by members of the museum staff under the guidance of William and Yulee Lazarus.<ref>White, Nancy Marie, "Grit-Tempered: Early Women Archaeologists in the Southeastern United States," pg. 163-177</ref> In 1971-1973 with the help of Depauw University's Robert J. Fornaro the mound was excavated to locate post holes and recover ceramic material that might fit vessels found earlier.<ref>Lazarus, Yulee, "Fort Walton Temple Mound (8OK6M): Further Test Excavations, DePauw 1973," Florida Anthropologist, vol. 28, no. 4, December 1975</ref> The last excavation of the Fort Walton Mound occurred in 1976 by then FSU graduate student Nina Thanz (Borremans). Thanz was tasked with making sure the reconstruction of a temple building being planned for the top of the mound would not disturb any human remains or artifacts during construction. She found several post holes from different structures built on top of the mound and evidence for a charnel house. Her findings of post holes became one source of the dimensions to the building structure that stands on the mound today. According to the first curator of the Indian Temple Mound Museum Yulee Lazarus the reconstruction of the temple building that currently stands on top of the mound was never intended on being a "replica," but rather to "bolster the imagination and interpretation of the Indians' use of the temple mound."<ref>Lazarus, Yulee, "A Temple-Style Shelter on the Fort Walton Temple Mound," Florida Journal of Anthropology, pg. 151.</ref>
==Fort Walton Culture== The mounds were built by the people of the [[Pensacola culture]], a regional variation of the [[Mississippian culture]].<ref name=GIBBON/> The [[Fort Walton culture]] was named for the site by archaeologist [[Gordon Willey]], but later work in the area has led archaeologists to believe the Fort Walton site was actually built and used by people of the contemporaneous Pensacola culture. The peoples of the Fort Walton culture used mostly sand, grit, [[Grog (clay)|grog]], or combinations of these materials as [[wikt:temper|tempering]] agents in their pottery, whereas the Pensacola culture peoples used the more typical Mississippian culture [[Shell tempered pottery|shell tempering]] for their pottery.<ref name=MARRINAN2007>{{cite journal|author1=Rochelle A. Marrinan|author2=Nancy Marie White|url=http://www.trailoffloridasindianheritage.org/pdf/fw1.pdf|title=Modeling Fort Walton Culture in Northwest Florida|journal=Southeastern Archaeology|volume=26|number=2-Winter|year=2007|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130403084151/http://www.trailoffloridasindianheritage.org/pdf/fw1.pdf|archivedate=2013-04-03|df=}}</ref> The site was abandoned by 1500 A.D. but the exact reason for the abandonment is unknown. It has been speculated that this was due to the arrival of European settlers, but this statement is unproven because the sites were already found abandoned by Spanish explorers years before.<ref>{{cite web|last=Cox|first=Dale|title=Explore Southern History|url=http://www.exploresouthernhistory.com/fortwaltonmound.html|work=Fort Walton Mound|accessdate=04/08/12}}</ref>
The people are recognized as being one of the most successful pre-Columbian cultures in regards to agriculture. A number of crops were successful including corn, beans, and squash. The mound itself appears in a common architectural fashion for the period with features such as a pyramidal base with a truncated top. The flat top was used for ceremonies, temples, and residences for high-ranking officials.<ref>{{cite web|title=Lost Worlds|url=http://www.lostworlds.org/fort_walton_mound.html|work=Florida: Fort Walton Mound|publisher=Lost Worlds|accessdate=04/08/12}}</ref>
==Fort Walton Beach Heritage Park & Cultural Center== Fort Walton Mound is now protected as part of the '''Fort Walton Beach Heritage Park & Cultural Center''', which features several museums included with admission: the '''Indian Temple Mound Museum''', '''Camp Walton Schoolhouse Museum''', '''Garnier Post Office Museum''' and '''Civil War Exhibits Building'''.
===Indian Temple Mound Museum=== The city-owned and operated Indian Temple Mound Museum features [[pre-Columbian]] artifacts found on site and from other locations, as well as a variety of exhibits on later Native American and Floridian history including artifacts from the European Explorers, local pirates and early settlers. The address is 139 Miracle Strip Pkwy SE, near the intersection of [[State Road 85 (Florida)|State Road 85]] and [[U.S. Route 98 in Florida|U.S. Route 98]], in the [[Florida Panhandle]]. The museum was first opened in 1962 and the current location was opened in 1972.
===Camp Walton Schoolhouse Museum=== The Camp Walton Schoolhouse Museum was the original one-room schoolhouse built in 1911.<ref>[http://www.fwb.org/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=109 Camp Walton Schoolhouse Museum]</ref> It opened for use for the community children from 1912 to 1936. Opened in 1976, the museum features early-20th-century desks and education items.
===Garnier Post Office Museum=== The Garnier Post Office Museum is an original small rural post office that displays the postal history of Camp Walton and Fort Walton with emphasis from 1900 to the 1950s. The site also served as a voting location. The museum opened in 1988.<ref>[http://www.fwb.org/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=113 Garnier Post Office Museum]</ref>
===Civil War Exhibits Building=== Opened in 2010, the Civil War Exhibits Building features displays about Florida's history during the [[American Civil War]].
==Gallery== <gallery> File:FortWaltonTempleMoundPlaque.jpg|Explanatory plaque File:FortWaltonBeachFlagMound.jpg|Indian Mound park File:FortWaltonBeachIndianTempleMoundEntrance.jpg|Indian Temple Mound park entrance </gallery>
==See also== * [[Southeastern Ceremonial Complex]] * [[List of Mississippian sites]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== {{Commons category|Fort Walton Mound}} * [http://fwb.org/museums/ Fort Walton Heritage Park and Cultural Center] * [http://www.flheritage.com/facts/reports/places/Counties/Okaloosa.cfm Okaloosa County listings] at [http://www.flheritage.com Florida's Office of Cultural and Historical Programs] * [http://www.exploresouthernhistory.com/fortwaltonmound.html Fort Walton Temple Mound] - Explore Southern History * [http://www.trailoffloridasindianheritage.org/o-Indian_Temple_Mound_Museum.html Indian Temple Mound Museum and Fort Walton Temple Mound] - Trail of Florida's Indian Heritage

revision.text:
{{Orphan|date=December 2014}}
[[File:Helga Grabstein.jpg|thumb|Helga Festival Gravestone]]
Calling „'''Helga!'''“ is a [[running gag]] at German concerts and festivals.
== Ritual== A person may call for a ''[[Helga]]'',<ref name="Neon">[http://www.neon.de/kat/freie_zeit/musik/88151.html Das Festival] auf neon.de</ref> others answer and come to a chorus like group effect.<ref>[http://www.faqs.org/faqs/de/music/faq/ <2004-04-14> Allgemeine Musiknewsgruppen-FAQ] auf faqs.org</ref> „Helga ist tot!“ (Helga is dead) denies the helgaing request.<ref>Julia Thiel: [http://www.einslive.de/musik/extras/2011/06/festival_abc.jsp Das Festival-ABC] auf einslive.de</ref> Further allegations se gravestones, memorials or graffiti. The background is unknown, some reports point to a rather rainy [[Hurricane Festival]] in [[Scheeßel]], where a high pressure cyclone called Helga was called for but didn't arrive in time. The call was namegiver for an annual prize for German festivals.<ref>[http://www.festivalguide.de/derhelga/ Der Helga]</ref> and is being used by a service company.<ref>[http://www.spiegel.de/unispiegel/wunderbar/festival-rituale-oliver-uschmann-ueber-crowdsurfing-und-helga-rufe-a-828387-4.html Rituale auf Festivals: Götter im Dixi, erhöret uns], Spiegel 2012 </ref>
== References == <references/>
[[Category:Running gags]] [[Category:German culture]] [[Category:Folklore by region]] [[Category:Festivals in Germany]]

{{More citations needed|date=November 2013}} {{Infobox media franchise | title = ''Hot Wheels: AcceleRacers'' | image = The Speed of Silence.jpg | caption = The DVD box art of the film '''''Hot Wheels: AcceleRacers - The Speed of Silence''''' | creator = Mark Edens

''Hot Wheels: AcceleRacers – The Ultimate Race'' | games = | vgs = | soundtracks = | toys = | footnotes = }} '''''Hot Wheels: AcceleRacers''''' is an [[animated series]] of four films by [[Mattel]]. It is [[computer animation|computer-animated]], produced by [[Rainmaker Studios|Mainframe Entertainment]] out of [[Vancouver]], [[British Columbia]], Canada, which also produced ''[[ReBoot]]'' and distributed by [[Warner Bros.]] Available on [[DVD]] and [[VHS]], it has also been shown on [[Cartoon Network]]. The series takes Mattel's [[Hot Wheels]] toy cars and puts them in a ''ReBoot''-like situation, with [[racing]] somewhat reminiscent of ''[[Tron]]''. This is a sequel to the 2003 animated film ''[[Hot Wheels: World Race]]'' and takes place in [[California]]. A soundtrack was distributed by [[Sony BMG]], and toys were sold in stores and given away in a [[McDonald's]] [[Happy Meal]]. A collectible card game and other merchandise were also made. ==Films== {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center;" |- ! rowspan="2"| Occupation ! colspan="4"| Films |- ! ''Ignition'' !
