{{About|the civil war that began in 2014|previous civil wars in Iraq|Iraqi civil war (disambiguation){{!}}Iraqi civil war|other wars in Iraq|Iraq War (disambiguation)}} {{Iraqi Civil War infobox}} The '''Iraqi Civil War''' was an armed conflict which began in January 2014 and ended in December 2017. In 2014, the [[Iraqi insurgency (2011–13)|Iraqi insurgency]] escalated into a [[civil war]] with the conquest of [[Fallujah]], [[Mosul]], [[Tikrit]] and in the major areas of [[Disputed territories of Northern Iraq|northern Iraq]] by the [[Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant]] (ISIL, also known as ISIS or IS). This resulted in the forced resignation of Iraqi [[Prime Minister of Iraq|Prime Minister]] [[Nouri al-Maliki]], as well as airstrikes by the United States, Iran, Syria, and at least a dozen other countries,<ref name="flying">{{cite web |url=http://www.slate.com/blogs/business_insider/2014/08/08/who_else_besides_americans_are_flying_fighter_jets_in_iraq.html|title=Who Else, Besides Americans, Are Flying Fighter Jets in Iraq?|work=Slate Magazine|accessdate=14 November 2014|deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141112044402/http://www.slate.com/blogs/business_insider/2014/08/08/who_else_besides_americans_are_flying_fighter_jets_in_iraq.html|archivedate=12 November 2014|df=}}</ref> the participation of Iranian troops<ref name="AJE-Iran">{{cite news |url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/middleeast/2014/08/iran-soldiers-iraq-islamic-state-2014823161322258630.html |title=Iran 'sent soldiers to fight in Iraq' |publisher=[[Al Jazeera America]] |date=23 August 2014 |accessdate=11 September 2014 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140920121525/http://www.aljazeera.com/news/middleeast/2014/08/iran-soldiers-iraq-islamic-state-2014823161322258630.html |archivedate=20 September 2014 |df= }}</ref> and military and logistical aid provided to Iraq by Russia.<ref name="flying" /> On 9 December 2017, Prime Minister [[Haider al-Abadi]] announced victory over ISIL,<ref name="end of war" /> though others warned that they expected ISIL to fight on via an insurgency, and by other means.<ref name=DOD-Australia2017-12-10a/><ref name=DerbyshireTimes2017-12-10a/><ref name=Reuters2017-12-10a/> ISIS switched to guerrilla 'hit and run' tactics in an effort to undermine the Iraqi government's effort to eradicate them.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-mideast-crisis-iraq-security/islamic-state-makes-comeback-in-iraq-with-switch-to-guerrilla-tactics-idUSKBN1KE0MH|title=Islamic State makes comeback in Iraq with switch to guerrilla tactics|first=Ahmed|last=Aboulenein|publisher=Reuters|date=24 July 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.defenseone.com/threats/2018/03/war-iraq-isnt-done-commanders-explain-why-and-whats-next/146889/|title=The War in Iraq Isn’t Done. Commanders Explain Why and What’s Next|work=Defense One|date=22 March 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.thenational.ae/opinion/comment/isil-sleeper-cells-in-iraq-are-a-warning-sign-the-extremist-group-is-already-reforming-1.716800|title=ISIL sleeper cells in Iraq are a warning sign the extremist group is already reforming|work=The National|date=28 March 2018}}</ref>
== Belligerents == {{Main|List of armed groups in the Iraqi Civil War}} Both the [[Iraqi Armed Forces]], [[Peshmerga|Kurdish Peshmerga]] and various [[Iraqi Turkmens|Turkmen]] [[Muslim]], [[Assyrian people|Assyrian]] [[Christian]], [[Yezidi]], [[Shabaki]], and [[Armenians|Armenian]] [[Christian]] forces are facing the [[Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant]]. Although some 35,000 Kurdish Peshmerga are incorporated into the Iraqi Armed Forces, most Peshmerga forces are operating under the command of the [[President of Iraqi Kurdistan]] in the [[Iraqi Kurdistan|Kurdish autonomous region]] of [[Iraq]].<ref name="IsisIraqiArmyPeshmerga1">{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/jun/12/how-battle-ready-isis-iraqi-army-peshmerga|title=How effective is Isis compared with the Iraqi army and Kurdish peshmerga?|newspaper=The Guardian|date=12 June 2014|deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140626063630/http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/jun/12/how-battle-ready-isis-iraqi-army-peshmerga|archivedate=26 June 2014|df=}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.vox.com/2014/8/12/5991425/kurds-iraq-kurdistan-peshmerga|title=6 essential facts about Iraq's Kurds|newspaper=Vox|date=12 August 2014|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170129203443/http://www.vox.com/2014/8/12/5991425/kurds-iraq-kurdistan-peshmerga|archivedate=29 January 2017|df=}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://ekurd.net/peshmerga-divided-from-within-2015-09-06|title=Iraqi Kurdish Peshmerga: Divided from Within|newspaper=Ekurd Daily|date=12 August 2014|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150925150326/http://ekurd.net/peshmerga-divided-from-within-2015-09-06|archivedate=25 September 2015|df=}}</ref> [[Assyrian people|Assyrian]] forces include: [[Syriac Military Council]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hurriyetdailynews.com/syriacs-establish-military-council-in-syria.aspx?pageID=238&nid=40329|title=Syriacs establish military council in Syria|work=[[Hürriyet Daily News]]|date=2 February 2013|accessdate=12 October 2014}}</ref> [[Nineveh Plain Forces]],<ref name="NPF4">{{cite web|url=https://warisboring.com/inside-the-christian-militias-defending-the-nineveh-plains-fe4a10babeed#.e83w8o5am|title=Inside the Christian Militias Defending the Nineveh Plains|publisher=Warisboring|date=7 March 2015|accessdate=8 January 2017|archive-url=http://webarchive.loc.gov/all/20160915094021/https://warisboring.com/inside%2Dthe%2Dchristian%2Dmilitias%2Ddefending%2Dthe%2Dnineveh%2Dplains%2Dfe4a10babeed#.e83w8o5am#.e83w8o5am|archive-date=2016-09-15|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref> [[Nineveh Plain Protection Units]],<ref name="aleteia">John Burger for Aletia. December 4, 2014 [http://www.aleteia.org/en/world/article/christians-in-iraq-forming-militia-to-defend-and-possibly-retake-ancestral-lands-5337839336161280 Christians in Iraq Forming Militia to Defend, and Possibly Retake, Ancestral Lands]</ref> [[Qaraqosh Protection Committee]],<ref name="Growing Stronger">{{cite news|url=https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=95343489 |publisher=NPR |title=Christian Security Forces Growing Stronger In Iraq |date=2008-10-06 |accessdate=2012-04-08}}</ref> and [[Dwekh Nawsha]].<ref name=almonoct2014>{{cite news |url=http://www.al-monitor.com/pulse/originals/2014/10/iraq-christian-paramilitary-forces-nineveh.html |title=Iraq's Christian paramilitaries split in IS fight |date=30 October 2014 |agency=[[Al-Monitor]] |accessdate=10 March 2015 |author=Henderson, Peter |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304202804/http://www.al-monitor.com/pulse/originals/2014/10/iraq-christian-paramilitary-forces-nineveh.html# |archive-date=2016-03-04 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref>
== Timeline ==
=== 2014 === {{Main|Timeline of the Iraq War (2014)}} In the course of their [[Anbar campaign (2013–14)|Anbar campaign]], [[Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant|ISIL]] militants seized at least 70% of the Anbar Province by June 2014,<ref name="auto">{{cite news|title=John Kerry holds talks in Iraq as more cities fall to ISIS militants|url=http://www.cnn.com/2014/06/23/world/meast/iraq-crisis/|agency=CNN|date=23 June 2014}}</ref> including the cities of [[Fallujah]],<ref name="auto1">{{cite web|url=http://www.foxnews.com/world/2014/01/04/iraq-army-battles-al-qaeda-linked-militants-to-regain-control-in-key-cities/|title=Al Qaeda-linked militants capture Fallujah during violent outbreak|publisher=Fox News Channel|date=4 January 2014}}</ref><ref name="7 News">{{cite web|url=http://au.news.yahoo.com/world/a/20602866/iraqs-fallujah-falls-to-qaeda-militants-as-65-killed/|title=Iraq's Fallujah falls to Qaeda militants as 65 killed|work=7 News|date=5 January 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140106031838/http://au.news.yahoo.com/world/a/20602866/iraqs-fallujah-falls-to-qaeda-militants-as-65-killed/|archivedate=6 January 2014|df=}}</ref> [[Al Qaim]],<ref name="21iraqi">{{cite web|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/news/world/militants-kills-21-leaders-iraq-article-1.1839547|title=Militants kill 21 Iraqi leaders, capture 2 border crossings|work=NY Daily News|accessdate=14 October 2014}}</ref> and half of the provincial capital of [[Ramadi]].<ref name="overruns">{{cite web|url=http://www.longwarjournal.org/archives/2014/07/islamic_state_overru.php|title=Islamic State overruns Camp Speicher, routs Iraqi forces|publisher=|accessdate=14 October 2014}}</ref> ISIL forces also infiltrated [[Abu Ghraib]] in [[Baghdad Governorate]].<ref name="iswiraq.blogspot.com">{{cite news|title=Iraq Update #42: Al-Qaeda in Iraq Patrols Fallujah; Aims for Ramadi, Mosul, Baghdad|url=http://iswiraq.blogspot.com/2014/01/iraq-update-42-al-qaeda-in-iraq-patrols.html|accessdate=5 January 2014|publisher=Institute for the Study of War|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140806123307/http://iswiraq.blogspot.com/2014/01/iraq-update-42-al-qaeda-in-iraq-patrols.html#!http://iswiraq.blogspot.com/2014/01/iraq-update-42-al-qaeda-in-iraq-patrols.html|archivedate=6 August 2014|deadurl=yes|df=}}</ref>
In early June 2014, following further [[Northern Iraq offensive (June 2014)|large-scale offensives in Iraq]], ISIL [[Northern Iraq offensive (June 2014)|seized control]] of [[Mosul]], the second most populous city in Iraq,<ref>{{cite news|last1=Al-Salhy|first1=Suadad|last2=Arango|first2=Tim|title=Sunni Militants Drive Iraqi Army Out of Mosul |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/06/11/world/middleeast/militants-in-mosul.html?_r=0|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|date=10 June 2014|deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170316130721/https://www.nytimes.com/2014/06/11/world/middleeast/militants-in-mosul.html?_r=0|archivedate=16 March 2017|df=}}</ref> the nearby town of [[Tal Afar]]<ref>{{cite news|last1=Al-Sanjary|first1=Ziad|last2=Rasheed|first2=Ahmed|title=Advancing Iraq rebels seize northwest town in heavy battle|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2014/06/15/us-iraq-security-idUSKBN0EP0KJ20140615|date=15 June 2014|agency=Reuters|accessdate=15 June 2014|deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140615061814/http://www.reuters.com/article/2014/06/15/us-iraq-security-idUSKBN0EP0KJ20140615|archivedate=15 June 2014|df=}}</ref> and most of the surrounding [[Nineveh province]].<ref name="auto2">{{cite web|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/middleeast/2014/06/reports-rebels-seize-control-iraq-mosul-2014610812970659.html |title=Rebels seize control of Iraq's Nineveh |publisher=Al Jazeera English |date=10 June 2014 |accessdate=2014-07-31}}</ref> ISIL also captured parts of Kirkuk and Diyala provinces<ref name="auto3">{{cite web|url=http://www.dailystar.com.lb/News/Middle-East/2014/Jun-10/259607-jihadists-seize-areas-in-iraqs-kirkuk-province-police.ashx#axzz34FqLUJ42 |title=Jihadists seize areas in Iraq's Kirkuk province: police |work=The Daily Star |date=2014-06-10 |accessdate=2014-07-31}}</ref> and [[Tikrit]], the administrative center of the Salahuddin Governorate,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/middleeast/2014/06/iraqi-city-tikrit-falls-isil-fighters-2014611135333576799.html|title=Iraq city of Tikrit falls to ISIS fighters|date=12 June 2014|website=Aljazeera.com|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140613012351/http://www.aljazeera.com/news/middleeast/2014/06/iraqi-city-tikrit-falls-isil-fighters-2014611135333576799.html|archivedate=13 June 2014|df=}}</ref> with the ultimate goal of capturing [[Baghdad]], the Iraqi capital.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Curry|first1=Colleen|title=A Simple and Useful Guide to Understanding the Conflict in Iraq|url=http://abcnews.go.com/International/simple-guide-understanding-conflict-iraq/story?id=24113794|date=13 June 2014|publisher=[[ABC News]]|accessdate=14 June 2014|deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140614012025/http://abcnews.go.com/International/simple-guide-understanding-conflict-iraq/story?id=24113794|archivedate=14 June 2014|df=}}</ref> IS was believed to have only 2,000–3,000 fighters up until the [[Northern Iraq offensive (June 2014)|Mosul campaign]], but during that campaign, it became evident that this number was a gross underestimate.<ref name=jcpa>{{cite web|last1=Neriah|first1=Jacques|date=11 June 2014|title=Is the Fall of Mosul in Iraq to the Jihadists a "Game Changer"?|url=http://jcpa.org/fall-mosul-iraq-jihadists-game-changer/|publisher=Jerusalem Center for Public Affairs|accessdate=16 June 2014|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140625122101/http://jcpa.org/fall-mosul-iraq-jihadists-game-changer/|archivedate=25 June 2014|df=}}</ref> There were also reports that the number of Sunni groups in Iraq that were opposed to the predominantly Shia government had joined ISIS, thus bolstering the group numbers.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Sherlock |first1=Ruth|last2=Malouf|first2=Carol|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/middleeast/iraq/10914567/Islamic-Army-of-Iraq-founder-Isis-and-Sunni-Islamists-will-march-on-Baghdad.html|title=Islamic Army of Iraq founder: Isis and Sunni Islamists will march on Baghdad|newspaper=[[The Daily Telegraph]]|date=20 June 2014|accessdate=22 June 2014}}</ref> However, the [[Kurds]]—who are mostly Sunnis—in the northeast of Iraq, were unwilling to be drawn into the conflict, and there were clashes in the area between ISIL and the Kurdish [[Peshmerga]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Collard|first1=Rebecca|title=Kurdish fighters mull whether to defend Iraq|date=20 June 2014|url=http://time.com/2905812/iraq-kurds-isis/|website=TIME|accessdate=22 June 2014|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140621183403/http://time.com/2905812/iraq-kurds-isis/|archivedate=21 June 2014|df=}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Windrem|first=Robert|date=20 June 2014|url=http://www.nbcnews.com/storyline/iraq-turmoil/sunnis-Shias-battle-are-iraqs-kurds-preparing-declare-independence-n136236|title=As Sunnis, Shiites Battle, Are Iraq's Kurds Preparing to Declare Independence?|newspaper=NBC News|accessdate=22 June 2014|deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150626151533/http://www.nbcnews.com/storyline/iraq-turmoil/sunnis-Shias-battle-are-iraqs-kurds-preparing-declare-independence-n136236|archivedate=26 June 2015|df=}}</ref>
ISIL [[Camp Speicher massacre|executed 1,700 Iraq soldiers]] who had surrendered in the fighting and released many images of mass executions via its Twitter feed and various websites.<ref>Norland, Rod; Rubin, Alissa A. "[https://www.nytimes.com/2014/06/16/world/middleeast/iraq.html?_r=0 Massacre Claim Shakes Iraq] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160726033949/http://www.nytimes.com/2014/06/16/world/middleeast/iraq.html?_r=0 |date=2016-07-26 }}" ''The New York Times''. 15 June 2014.</ref>
[[File:Iraqi Army tank-North of Baghdad.png|thumb|left|[[Peshmerga]] tank at the frontlines, south of [[Kirkuk]], in June 2014 ]]
In late June, ISIS militants captured two key crossings in Anbar, a day after seizing the border crossing at [[Al-Qa'im border crossing|Al-Qaim]]. According to analysts, capturing these crossings could aid ISIL in transporting weapons and equipment to different battlefields.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-27966774|title=Sunni militants 'seize Iraq's western border crossings'|date=22 June 2014|accessdate=22 June 2014|publisher=BBC News|deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140622171004/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-27966774|archivedate=22 June 2014|df=}}</ref> Two days later, the [[Syrian Air Force]] bombed ISIL positions in Iraq. Iraqi Prime Minister [[Nouri al-Maliki]] stated: "There was no coordination involved, but we welcome this action. We welcome any Syrian strike against Isis because this group targets both Iraq and Syria."<ref>{{cite news|last1=Chulov|first1=Martin|last2=Hawramy|first2=Fazel|title=Isis: Maliki hails Syrian air raids in Iraq as leaving both states 'winners'|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/jun/26/nouri-maliki-admits-syria-air-raids-isis-iraq|accessdate=14 July 2014|newspaper=The Guardian|date=27 June 2014|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140714155423/http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/jun/26/nouri-maliki-admits-syria-air-raids-isis-iraq|archivedate=14 July 2014|df=}}</ref>
At this point, ''[[The Jerusalem Post]]'' reported that the [[Presidency of Barack Obama|Obama administration]] had requested US$500 million from the [[United States Congress|US Congress]] to use in the training and arming of "moderate" [[Syrian opposition|Syrian rebels]] fighting against the Syrian government, in order to counter the growing threat posed by ISIS in Syria and Iraq.<ref>"[http://www.jpost.com/Middle-East/Obama-seeks-500-million-from-congress-to-train-moderate-Syrian-rebels-to-fight-ISIS-360845 Obama seeks $500 million from Congress to train 'moderate' Syrian rebels to fight ISIS] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160213092133/http://www.jpost.com/Middle-East/Obama-seeks-500-million-from-congress-to-train-moderate-Syrian-rebels-to-fight-ISIS-360845 |date=2016-02-13 }}" ''The Jerusalem Post''. 28 June 2014.</ref>
On 29 June, ISIL announced the establishment of a new [[caliphate]]. [[Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi]] was appointed its [[caliph]], and group formally changed its name to the Islamic State.<ref name="newname">{{cite news|last=Withnall|first=Adam|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/middle-east/isis-declares-new-islamic-state-in-middle-east-with-abu-bakr-albaghdadi-as-emir-removing-iraq-and-syria-from-its-name-9571374.html|title=Iraq crisis: Isis changes name and declares its territories a new Islamic state with 'restoration of caliphate' in Middle East|newspaper=[[The Independent]]|date=29 June 2014|accessdate=29 June 2014|deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140630105143/http://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/middle-east/isis-declares-new-islamic-state-in-middle-east-with-abu-bakr-albaghdadi-as-emir-removing-iraq-and-syria-from-its-name-9571374.html|archivedate=30 June 2014|df=}}</ref> Four days later, Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi, the self-proclaimed caliph of the new Islamic State, said that Muslims should unite to capture [[Rome]] in order to "own the world."<ref>{{cite news|last=Rousselle|first=Christine |url=http://townhall.com/tipsheet/christinerousselle/2014/07/02/leader-of-islamic-state-claims-rome-will-be-conquered-next-n1858160|date=2 July |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140703011229/http://townhall.com/tipsheet/christinerousselle/2014/07/02/leader-of-islamic-state-claims-rome-will-be-conquered-next-n1858160|archivedate=3 July 2014|df=}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=McElory|first=Damien|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/middleeast/syria/10939235/Rome-will-be-conquered-next-says-leader-of-Islamic-State.html|newspaper=[[The Daily Telegraph]]|title=Rome will be conquered next, says leader of 'Islamic State'|accessdate=3 July 2014|deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140702204655/http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/middleeast/syria/10939235/Rome-will-be-conquered-next-says-leader-of-Islamic-State.html|archivedate=2 July 2014|df=}}</ref> He called on Muslims all over the world to unite behind him as their leader.<ref name="WorldLeader">{{cite news|title=ISIS leader calls for global Muslim obedience|url=http://www.middleeaststar.com/index.php/sid/223540031/scat/940f2bfd509e743b/ht/ISIS-leader-calls-for-global-Muslim-obedience|date=5 July 2014|accessdate=7 July 2014|newspaper=Middle East Star|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140714201922/http://www.middleeaststar.com/index.php/sid/223540031/scat/940f2bfd509e743b/ht/ISIS-leader-calls-for-global-Muslim-obedience#|archivedate=2014-07-14|df=}}</ref>
On 24 July, ISIL blew up the [[Mosques and shrines of Mosul|Mosque and tomb of the Prophet Yunus (Jonah)]] in Mosul,<ref>{{cite news|title=Iraq jihadists blow up 'Jonah's tomb' in Mosul|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/middleeast/iraq/10989959/Iraq-jihadists-blow-up-Jonahs-tomb-in-Mosul.html|accessdate=25 July 2014|newspaper=The Telegraph|agency=[[Agence France-Presse]]|date=25 July 2014|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140726131010/http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/middleeast/iraq/10989959/Iraq-jihadists-blow-up-Jonahs-tomb-in-Mosul.html|archivedate=26 July 2014|df=}}</ref> with no reported casualties.<ref>{{cite news|title=Isis militants blow up Jonah's tomb|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/jul/24/isis-militants-blow-up-jonah-tomb|accessdate=25 July 2014|newspaper=The Guardian|agency=Associated Press|date=24 July 2014|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140725112505/http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/jul/24/isis-militants-blow-up-jonah-tomb|archivedate=25 July 2014|df=}}</ref> Residents in the area said that ISIS had erased a piece of Iraqi heritage.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://online.wsj.com/articles/jihadists-in-iraq-erase-cultural-heritage-1406313661|title=Jihadists in Iraq Erase Cultural Heritage|last=Malas|first=Nour|newspaper=The Wall Street Journal|date=25 July 2014|accessdate=27 July 2014|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140726220823/http://online.wsj.com/articles/jihadists-in-iraq-erase-cultural-heritage-1406313661|archivedate=26 July 2014|df=}}</ref> Jonah's tomb was also an important holy site in the Jewish heritage as well.<ref>{{Cite news|url =http://www.ynet.co.il/articles/0,7340,L-4550067,00.html|title=Da'esh destroys the Tomb of Jonah in Iraq |date=26 July 2014|newspaper=Ynet|accessdate=21 April 2018|deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141009144434/http://www.ynet.co.il/articles/0%2C7340%2CL-4550067%2C00.html|archivedate =2014-10-09|df =}}</ref> A few days later, ISIL also blew up the Nabi Shiyt (Prophet [[Seth]]) shrine in [[Mosul]]. Sami al-Massoudi, deputy head of the [[Shia]] endowment agency which oversees holy sites, confirmed the destruction and added that ISIS had taken artifacts from the shrine to an unknown location.<ref>{{cite news|title=ISIS destroys Prophet Sheth shrine in Mosul|url=http://english.alarabiya.net/en/News/middle-east/2014/07/26/ISIS-destroy-Prophet-Sheth-shrine-in-Mosul-.html|publisher=[[Al Arabiya]]|date=26 July 2014|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140729003950/http://english.alarabiya.net/en/News/middle-east/2014/07/26/ISIS-destroy-Prophet-Sheth-shrine-in-Mosul-.html|archivedate=29 July 2014|df=}}</ref>
In an [[Northern Iraq offensive (August 2014)|August offensive]], ISIL captured [[Sinjar]] and a number of other towns in the north of the country. Almost 200,000 civilians, mostly [[Yazidis]], managed to flee from the fighting in [[Sinjar]] city,<ref name=seize3>[https://www.nytimes.com/2014/08/04/world/middleeast/iraq.html Sunni Extremists in Iraq Seize 3 Towns From Kurds and Threaten Major Dam] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141015200018/http://www.nytimes.com/2014/08/04/world/middleeast/iraq.html |date=2014-10-15 }}. ''New York Times'', 3 August 2014. Retrieved 7 March 2015.</ref><ref name="BBC7Aug" /> about 50,000 of them fled into the [[Sinjar Mountains]],<ref name="BBC7Aug" /> where they were trapped without food, water or medical care,<ref>[http://edition.cnn.com/2014/08/06/world/meast/iraq-crisis-minority-persecution/index.html?hpt=hp_t3 ‘Iraqi Yazidi lawmaker: 'Hundreds of my people are being slaughtered'’] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151208104543/http://edition.cnn.com/2014/08/06/world/meast/iraq-crisis-minority-persecution/index.html?hpt=hp_t3 |date=2015-12-08 }}. CNN, 6 August 2014. Retrieved 16 February 2015.</ref> facing starvation and dehydration.<ref name="BBC7Aug">{{cite news |date=7 August 2014 |title=UN Security Council condemns attacks by Iraqi jihadists |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-middle-east-28699832 |publisher=BBC News |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140808001143/http://www.bbc.com/news/world-middle-east-28699832 |archivedate=8 August 2014 |accessdate=7 March 2015 }}</ref> They had been threatened with death if they refused conversion to the Islam. A UN representative said that "a humanitarian tragedy is unfolding in Sinjar."<ref>{{cite news|last1=Salih |first1=Mohammed|last2=van Wilgenburg|first2=Wladimir|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/middleeast/2014/08/iraqi-yazidis-if-move-they-will-kill-us-20148513656188206.html|title=Iraqi Yazidis: 'If we move they will kill us'|date=5 August 2014|publisher=Al Jazeera|accessdate=5 August 2014|deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140806132648/http://www.aljazeera.com/news/middleeast/2014/08/iraqi-yazidis-if-move-they-will-kill-us-20148513656188206.html |archivedate=6 August 2014|df=}}</ref> By the end of the month, [[Sinjar massacre|ISIL massacred 5,000 Yazidi men]], with killings running in the hundreds in different villages.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Hopkins|first1=Steve|title=Full horror of the Yazidis who didn't escape Mount Sinjar: UN confirms 5,000 men were executed and 7,000 women are now kept as sex slaves|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2792552/full-horror-yazidis-didn-t-escape-mount-sinjar-confirms-5-000-men-executed-7-000-women-kept-sex-slaves.html|work=The [[Daily Mail]]|date=14 October 2014|accessdate=13 March 2015|deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20141017143143/http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2792552/full-horror-yazidis-didn-t-escape-mount-sinjar-confirms-5-000-men-executed-7-000-women-kept-sex-slaves.html|archivedate=17 October 2014|df=}}</ref> In addition, during this latest offensive, the Islamic State advanced to within 30 km of the Iraqi Kurdish capital of [[Erbil]] in northern Iraq.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ynewsiq.com/index.php?aa=news&id22=7265#.U-dPEZp0y00|title=مصادر كردية: "الدولة الإسلامية" على بعد 30 كيلومترا من إربيل|website=ynewsiq.com|date=9 August 2014|accessdate=10 August 2014|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140812223411/http://ynewsiq.com/index.php?aa=news&id22=7265#.U-dPEZp0y00|archivedate=12 August 2014|df=}}</ref><ref>{{cite August 2014|df=}}</ref>
Prompted by the siege and killings of the Yazidis, on 7 August, President Obama authorized [[American-led intervention in Iraq (2014–present)|targeted airstrikes in Iraq against ISIL]], along with airdrops of aid.<ref>{{cite news|title=Obama Authorized Targeted Airstrikes in Iraq Against Islamic Militants, Along with Airdrops|url=http://bigstory.ap.org/article/obama-authorizes-targeted-airstrikes-iraq-against-islamic-militants-along-airdrops|accessdate=7 August 2014|work=Associated Press|date=7 August 2014}}</ref> The UK offered the US assistance with surveillance and refuelling, and planned humanitarian airdrops to Iraqi refugees.<ref>{{cite news|title=UK planes to drop emergency aid to Iraqi refugees |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-28701642|accessdate=8 August 2014|publisher=BBC News|date=8 August 2014|deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140808073556/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-28701642|archivedate=8 August 2014|df=}}</ref> The US asserted that the systematic destruction of the Yazidi people by the Islamic State was genocide.<ref>{{cite news|last=Noack|first=Rick|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/worldviews/wp/2014/08/08/when-obama-talks-about-iraq-his-use-of-the-word-genocide-is-vital/|title=When Obama talks about Iraq, his use of the word 'genocide' is vital|newspaper=The Washington Post|date=8 August 2014|accessdate=12 August 2014}}</ref> The Arab League also accused the Islamic State of committing crimes against humanity.<ref>{{cite news|title=Arab League denounces ISIS attacks as "crimes against humanity"|url=http://english.alarabiya.net/en/News/middle-east/2014/08/11/U-S-weighs-options-to-evacuate-trapped-Yazidis-.html|accessdate=17 August 2014|newspaper=Al Arabiya|date=11 August On 31 August, the United States, France, United Kingdom and Australia began humanitarian aid drops like food, water and medical supplies, to help prevent a potential massacre against the Shi'a Turkmen minority in Amirli. The US also carried out air strikes on ISIS positions around and near Amirli. Iraqi officials stated that they had reached Amirli and broken the siege and that the military was fighting to clear the areas around the town. This is known to be the first major turning point against the ISIL in [[Iraq]].<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-middle-east-29003321 |title=Iraqi forces 'reach besieged Amerli' |publisher=BBC News |date=31 August 2014 |accessdate=10 September 2014 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140906212657/http://www.bbc.com/news/world-middle-east-29003321 |archivedate=6 September 2014 |df= }}</ref>
In September, the United States sent an additional 250 US troops to protect American personnel,<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.foxnews.com/politics/2014/09/03/obama-to-send-approximately-350-additional-military-personnel-to-iraq/ |title=Obama to send approximately 350 additional military personnel to Iraq |newspaper=[[Fox News Channel]] |date=3 September 2014 |accessdate=10 September 2014 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140908153420/http://www.foxnews.com/politics/2014/09/03/obama-to-send-approximately-350-additional-military-personnel-to-iraq/ |archivedate=8 September 2014 |df= }}</ref> while the first engagement of the British military against ISIS targets took place when a British [[Panavia Tornado]] jet dropped a [[Paveway IV]] bomb on "a heavy weapon position" operated by ISIS in northwest Iraq at the end of the month.<ref>[http://www.flightglobal.com/news/articles/raf-tornados-strike-first-islamic-state-targets-404310/ RAF Tornadoes strike first Islamic State targets] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160213222139/https://www.flightglobal.com/news/articles/raf-tornados-strike-first-islamic-state-targets-404310/ |date=2016-02-13 }} – 2014|df=}}</ref>
In mid-October [[Fall of Hīt (2014)|ISIL forces captured the city of Hīt]] after the 300-strong Iraqi Army garrison abandoned and set afire its local base and supplies. As a result, an estimated 180,000 civilians (including refugees of the previous Anbar offensive) attempted to flee the area.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.news.com.au/world/islamic-state-militants-overrun-the-strategic-city-of-heet-and-claim-half-syrian-border-town-of-kobane/story-fndir2ev-1227089645199|title=Islamic State militants overrun the strategic city of Heet and claim half Syrian border town of Kobane|work=NewsComAu|accessdate=3 March 2015|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150131012822/http://www.news.com.au/world/islamic-state-militants-overrun-the-strategic-city-of-heet-and-claim-half-syrian-border-town-of-kobane/story-fndir2ev-1227089645199|archivedate=31 January 2015|df=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.unhcr.org/543d10119.html|title=UNHCR – Iraq's displacement crisis deepens as civilians flee latest ISIS offensive|author=United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees|publisher=UNHCR|accessdate=14 November 2014|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141018215638/http://www.unhcr.org/543d10119.html|archivedate=18 October 2014|df=}}</ref> Later that month, [[Operation Ashura]] is launched by Iraqi forces and Iranian-backed Shia militas, scoring a major victory and retaking the strategic town of [[Jurf al-Sakhar]] near Baghdad, and securing the way for millions of Shia pilgrims who were going to Karbala and Najaf On the [[Day of Ashura]]. Kurdish forces, meanwhile, recaptured [[Zumar]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.ibtimes.co.uk/iraqi-forces-recapture-key-towns-isis-following-22-us-air-strikes-1471756|title=Iraqi Forces Recapture Key Towns from Isis Following 22 US Air Strikes|last=Akinyemi|first=Aaron|date=October 25, 2014|work=International Business Times|accessdate=|deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304081539/http://www.ibtimes.co.uk/iraqi-forces-recapture-key-towns-isis-following-22-us-air-strikes-1471756 |archivedate=March 4, 2016|df=}}</ref>
On 21 October, ISIL seized terrain north of the Sinjar Mountains, thus cutting the area's escape route to Kurdish areas. The Yazidi militias then withdrew from there into the mountains, where the number of Yazidi civilian refugees was estimated at 2,000–7,000.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.agathocledesyracuse.com/archives/115|title=Iraq Sinjar battle (21 Oct 2014)|work=Agathocle de Syracuse|date=21 October 2014|accessdate=24 March 2015|deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150226111009/http://www.agathocledesyracuse.com/archives/115|archivedate=26 February 2015|df=}}</ref> The mountains had once again been partially surrounded by ISIL.<ref name="Clatch22.12.14">{{cite news|url=http://www.mcclatchydc.com/2014/12/22/250901_islamic-state-counterattacks-refinery.html?&rh=1 |title=Islamic State counterattacks refinery as fight for Iraq swings back and forth |agency=McClatchy DC |accessdate=24 March 2015 |date=22 December 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150128070705/http://www.mcclatchydc.com/2014/12/22/250901_islamic-state-counterattacks-refinery.html?&rh=1 |archivedate=January 28, 2015}}</ref>
In mid-November, Iraqi forces retook control of most part of the [[Battle of Baiji (October–December 2014)|strategic city Baiji]] from the Islamic State<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.naharnet.com/stories/en/154376-iraqi-forces-advance-in-jihadist-held-baiji|title=Iraqi Forces Advance in Jihadist-Held Baiji|work=Naharnet|date=7 November 2014|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161108195030/http://www.naharnet.com/stories/en/154376-iraqi-forces-advance-in-jihadist-held-baiji|archivedate=8 November 2016|df=}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Iraq troops 'push Islamic State from oil town of Baiji' |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-middle-east-30052714 |publisher=BBC News |date=2014-11-14 |accessdate=2014-11-18 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141117021756/http://www.bbc.com/news/world-middle-east-30052714 |archivedate=2014-11-17 |df= }}</ref> and broke the siege of the nearby oil refinery.<ref>{{cite news |title=Iraqi security forces enter Baiji refinery |url=http://english.alarabiya.net/en/News/middle-east/2014/11/18/Iraqi-security-forces-enter-Baiji-refinery.html |publisher=Al Arabiya |date=2014-11-18 |accessdate=2014-11-18 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141121104309/http://english.alarabiya.net/en/News/middle-east/2014/11/18/Iraqi-security-forces-enter-Baiji-refinery.html |archivedate=2014-11-21 |df= }}</ref> However, by the following month, ISIL recaptured Baiji and reestablished the siege of the refinery.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ibtimes.com/isis-iraq-kurds-recapture-mount-sinjar-islamic-state-group-retakes-baiji-oil-refinery-1764416|title=ISIS In Iraq: Kurds Recapture Mount Sinjar As Islamic State Group Retakes Baiji Oil Refinery|author=Avaneesh Pandey|date=22 December 2014|work=International Business Times|accessdate=11 June 2015|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150503102302/http://www.ibtimes.com/isis-iraq-kurds-recapture-mount-sinjar-islamic-state-group-retakes-baiji-oil-refinery-1764416|archivedate=3 May 2015|df=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.business-standard.com/article/news-ians/iraqi-army-retake-military-airbase-outside-tal-afar-114122200044_1.html|title=Iraqi army retake military airbase outside Tal Afar|author=IANS|date=22 December 2014|publisher=|accessdate=11 June 2015|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150611064332/http://www.business-standard.com/article/news-ians/iraqi-army-retake-military-airbase-outside-tal-afar-114122200044_1.html|archivedate=11 June 2015|df=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://rudaw.net/english/middleeast/iraq/22122014|title=Iraq|work=Rudaw|accessdate=11 June 2015|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150624220019/http://rudaw.net/english/middleeast/iraq/22122014|archivedate=24 June 2015|df=}}</ref>
On 17 December, [[Peshmerga]] forces, backed by 50 US-led coalition airstrikes on ISIL positions,<ref name=NY19-12 /> launched an offensive to liberate Sinjar<ref name=NY19-12>{{cite web|url=http://www.newyorker.com/news/news-desk/early-success-kurds-sinjar|title=An Early Success for the Kurds in Sinjar|work=The New Yorker|accessdate=24 March 2015|date=19 December 2014|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150327021028/http://www.newyorker.com/news/news-desk/early-success-kurds-sinjar?mbid=rss|archivedate=27 March 2015|df=}}</ref> and to break the partial ISIL siege of the Sinjar Mountains.<ref name=Clatch22.12.14 /> In less than two days, the siege was broken. After ISIL forces retreated, Kurdish fighters were initially faced with the clearing out mines around the area,<ref name=Alj.Am.19-12-14>{{cite web|url=http://america.aljazeera.com/articles/2014/12/19/peshmerga-sinjarisil.html|title=ISIL land mines frustrate effort to get aid to freed Mount Sinjar Yazidis|publisher=Aljazeera America|date=19 December 2014|accessdate=17 February 2015|deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150128054433/http://america.aljazeera.com/articles/2014/12/19/peshmerga-sinjarisil.html|archivedate=28 January 2015|df=}}</ref> but quickly opened a land corridor to those mountains, enabling Yazidis to be evacuated. The operation left 100 ISIL fighters dead.<ref name=NY19-12 />
Later on 21 December, Syrian Kurdish [[People's Protection Units|YPG]] fighters south of the mountain range reached Peshmerga lines, thus linking their two fronts.<ref name="Clatch22.12.14" /> The next day, the YPG broke through ISIL lines, thus opening a corridor from [[Syria]] to the town of Sinjar. By the evening, the Peshmerga took control of much of Sinjar.<ref name=Clatch22.12.14 />
=== 2015 === {{Main|Timeline of the Iraq War (2015)}} [[File:Captured DAESH fighter and Iraqi defenders (2).jpg|thumb|left|Captured ISIL militant is guarded by [[Popular Mobilization Forces|PMF]] fighters after [[counter-insurgency]] operations in [[Saladin Governorate]], April 2015 ]]
In late January, Iraqi forces recaptured the entire province of [[Diyala Province|Diyala]] from the Islamic State.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://news.yahoo.com/iraq-forces-liberate-diyala-province-jihadists-130947834.html|title=Iraq forces 'liberate' Diyala province from IS|date=26 January 2015|work=Yahoo News|accessdate=11 June 2015|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150722035006/http://news.yahoo.com/iraq-forces-liberate-diyala-province-jihadists-130947834.html|archivedate=22 July 2015|df=}}</ref> Also, beginning of the [[Mosul offensive (2015)|Mosul Offensive]] in which [[Peshmerga]] forces captured large amount of territory surrounding [[Mosul]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/middle_east/kurds-say-they-have-ejected-islamic-state-from-a-big-area-in-northern-iraq/2015/01/21/ac459372-a1c6-11e4-b146-577832eafcb4_story.html|title=Kurds say they have ejected Islamic State militants from large area in northern Iraq|author=Loveday Morris|date=22 January 2015|work=Washington Post}}</ref>
On 2 March, [[Second Battle of Tikrit (March 2015)|Second Battle of Tikrit]] began<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-31699632|title=Iraq 'seizes districts from IS' in Tikrit advance|publisher=BBC News|accessdate=11 June 2015|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150614064238/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-31699632|archivedate=14 June 2015|df=}}</ref> and after more than a month of hard fighting, government troops and pro-Iranian Shiite militias overcame ISIL fighters and took Tikrit.<ref name="ISIL sleepers killed">{{cite web|url=http://www.iraqinews.com/iraq-war/130-isis-elements-killed-sleeper-cells-found-tikrit/|title=130 ISIS elements killed, sleeper cells found in Tikrit|author=Abdelhak Mamoun|publisher=Iraqi News|accessdate=30 April 2015}}</ref> This success was off-set in late May, by ISIL's capture of the provincial capital of Ramadi in Anbar province.<ref>{{cite web |title=ISIL seizes control of Iraq's Ramadi |url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/2015/05/isil-overruns-iraqi-holdout-ramadi-150517142811552.html |publisher=Al Jazeera|accessdate=18 May 2015 |date=18 May 2015}}</ref>
On 17 July, a [[suicide bomb]]er [[2015 Khan Bani Saad bombing|detonated a car bomb]] in a crowded marketplace in the city of [[Khan Bani Saad]] during [[Eid al-Fitr]] celebrations, killing 120–130 people and injuring 130 more. Twenty more people were reported missing since the bombing.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/at-least-130-dead-in-iraq-after-massive-bomb-attack/2015/07/18/01798182-74b9-4388-a2ed-cee7fd54976d_story.html|title=At least 130 are dead in Iraq after a massive bomb attack|author=Mustafa Salim|date=18 July 2015|work=Washington Post}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-middle-east-33577817|title=Iraq violence: Car bomb kills scores in mainly Shia town|publisher=BBC News|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150717235140/http://www.bbc.com/news/world-middle-east-33577817|archivedate=2015-07-17|df=}}</ref>
On 13 August, a suicide bomber [[2015 Baghdad truck bombing|detonated a truck bomb]] in a crowded marketplace in [[Sadr City]], [[Baghdad]], killing at least 75 people and injuring 212 more.<ref name="reuters1">{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2015/08/13/us-mideast-crisis-iraq-violence-idUSKCN0QI0DE20150813|title=Islamic State claims huge truck bomb attack in Baghdad's Sadr City|agency=Reuters|accessdate=13 August 2015|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150813055223/http://www.reuters.com/article/2015/08/13/us-mideast-crisis-iraq-violence-idUSKCN0QI0DE20150813|archivedate=13 August 2015|df=}}</ref> On 27 August, a suicide bomber assassinated General Abdel Rahman Abu Ragheef, deputy commander of operations in the province of Anbar, and Brigadier Safeen Abdel Majeed, a divisional commander.<ref>{{cite web|title=Iraq conflict: Bomb kills two generals near Ramadi|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-34071169|publisher=BBC News|accessdate=2015-09-02|deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150904021132/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-34071169|archivedate=2015-09-04|df=}}</ref>
ISIL forces lost Sinjar on November 13 to Kurdish forces.<ref name=NYT13>{{cite news |author1=Michael R. Gordon |author2=Rukmini Callimachi |title=Kurdish Fighters Retake Iraqi City of Sinjar From ISIS |work=[[New York Times]] |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/11/14/world/middleeast/sinjar-iraq-islamic-state.html |date=13 November 2015 |accessdate=13 November 2015 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151113134238/http://www.nytimes.com/2015/11/14/world/middleeast/sinjar-iraq-islamic-state.html |archivedate=13 November 2015 |df= }}</ref>
During 16–17 December, ISIL forces mounted a [[Nineveh Plains Offensive|major offensive]] north-east of Mosul against Kurdish position but were repelled.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/national-security/islamic-state-offensive-in-northern-iraq-although-repelled-shows-groups-resilience/2015/12/17/752f207c-a4ec-11e5-b53d-972e2751f433_story.html?hpid=hp_hp-top-table-main_isiraq1030p%3Ahomepage%2Fstory|title=Islamic State offensive in northern Iraq, although repelled, shows group's resilience|author=Missy Ryan|date=17 December 2015|work=Washington Post|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151219000956/https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/national-security/islamic-state-offensive-in-northern-iraq-although-repelled-shows-groups-resilience/2015/12/17/752f207c-a4ec-11e5-b53d-972e2751f433_story.html?hpid=hp_hp-top-table-main_isiraq1030p%3Ahomepage%2Fstory |archivedate=19 December 2015|df=}}</ref> Starting December 22, the Iraqi Army began a campaign to recapture [[Ramadi]].<ref name="Ramadi falls">{{cite web|url=https://www.theatlantic.com/international/archive/2015/12/iraq-ramadi-isis/422001/|title=Ramadi Is 'Fully Liberated'|first=Krishnadev|last=Calamur|publisher=|accessdate=August 15, 2016}}</ref> On December 28, Iraq declared Ramadi liberated from ISIL forces and under the control of the Iraqi government.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-35188479|title=Iraq declares Ramadi liberated from Islamic State|publisher=BBC News|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151228133127/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-35188479|archivedate=2015-12-28|df=}}</ref>
=== 2016 === {{Main|Timeline of the Iraq War (2016)}} Iraqi forces regained control of [[Hīt offensive (2016)|Hīt]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/2016/04/iraqi-forces-oust-isil-key-anbar-town-160408144126609.html|title=Iraqi forces oust ISIL from key Anbar town|publisher=Al Jazeera}}</ref> and [[Ar-Rutbah offensive (2016)|Ar-Rutbah]]<ref name="ISIL pulls out">{{cite web|url=https://www.dailystar.com.lb/News/Middle-East/2016/Mar-13/341957-isis-pulls-out-of-town-in-iraqs-anbar-general.ashx|title=ISIS pulls out of town in Iraq's Anbar: general|work=The Daily Star Newspaper - Lebanon|accessdate=March 24, 2016}}</ref> in offensive operations in 2016 and then Fallujah as well in the [[Battle of Fallujah (2016)|Third Battle of Fallujah]] ending in June 2016.<ref name="Fallujah fully liberated">{{cite web|url=https://www.yahoo.com/amphtml/news/iraqi-commander-fallujah-fully-liberated-082637513.html|title=Fallujah fully liberated from IS group, Iraqi commander says|publisher=|accessdate=30 June 2016}}</ref>
On 16 October 2016, the [[Battle of Mosul (2016–2017)|Battle of Mosul]] began.<ref name="ibt1016">{{cite news |last1=Haddad |first1=Tareq |title='US military has started shelling Mosul' says Peshmerga commander |url=http://www.ibtimes.co.uk/us-military-has-started-shelling-mosul-says-peshmerga-commander-1586650 |accessdate=17 October 2016 |work=International Business Times |date=16 October 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161018173357/http://www.ibtimes.co.uk/us-military-has-started-shelling-mosul-says-peshmerga-commander-1586650 |archivedate=18 October 2016 |df=dmy-all}}</ref>
=== 2017 === {{Main|Timeline of the Iraq War (2017)}} In May, a member from the [[Canadian Special Operations Forces Command|Canadian Special Forces]] [[Joint Task Force 2]] disrupted a Daesh attack on Iraqi security forces. The target was successfully hit at 3,540 metres from a high-rise, setting the world's longest recorded sniper kill.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/politics/canadian-elite-special-forces-sniper-sets-record-breaking-kill-shot-in-iraq/article35415651/|title=Canadian elite special forces sniper makes record-breaking kill shot in Iraq|access-date=2017-12-11}}</ref>
In April, the [[Iraqi Army]], with the help of the [[Popular Mobilization Forces]], launched the [[Western Nineveh offensive (2017)|Western Nineveh offensive]] to capture territory west of Mosul.<ref name="launch">{{cite web|url=http://www.longwarjournal.org/archives/2017/04/iraqi-popular-mobilization-forces-launch-operation-southwest-of-mosul.php|title=Iraqi Popular Mobilization Forces launch operation southwest of Mosul - FDD's Long War Journal|website=FDD's Long War Journal}}</ref> The PMU were able to reach the [[Iraq–Syria border]], meeting up with territory controlled by the [[Syrian Democratic Forces]].
On 10 July, Iraqi Army forces [[Battle of Mosul (2016–2017)|captured Mosul]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2017/07/10/middleeast/mosul-what-next/index.html|title=Mosul now freed from ISIS: What's next for the city left in ruins?|website=CNN|date=10 July 2017|accessdate=15 September 2017}}</ref> Following the victory in Mosul, the Iraqi Army launched operations to sweep what remained of ISIL-controlled territory in the country. The [[Tal Afar offensive (2017)|Tal Afar offensive]] was launched on 20 August<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/2017/08/iraq-launches-offensive-retake-tal-afar-isil-170820003243879.html|title=Iraq launches offensive to retake Tal Afar from ISIL|publisher=Al Jazeera|date=20 August 2017|accessdate=15 September 2017}}</ref> and completed by 31 August with a major Iraqi Army victory.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://edition.cnn.com/2017/08/31/middleeast/iraq-tal-afar-isis/index.html|title=Tal Afar 'liberated' from ISIS|publisher=CNN|date=31 August 2017|accessdate=15 September 2017}}</ref> The [[Hawija offensive (2017)|Hawija offensive]] started in late September and was complete by 5 October.<ref name="auto4">{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-middle-east-41509085|title=Iraq forces retake town of Hawija from IS|date=5 October 2017|publisher=BBC News|accessdate=5 October 2017}}</ref>
On 25 September, [[Iraqi Kurdistan]] held an unofficial [[Iraqi Kurdistan independence referendum, 2017|independence referendum]]. Turnout was reported to be 72.83% with 92.73% voting in favor of independence from Iraq. In response to the referendum, the Iraqi Army launched a short [[Battle of Kirkuk (2017)|offensive]] on 15 October against Iraqi Kurdistan to recapture the disputed city of Kirkuk with the help of the Talabani family and some PUK members.<ref name="KirkukIraq">{{cite web|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/2017/10/baghdad-iraqi-forces-full-control-kirkuk-171016133409720.html|title=Baghdad: Iraqi forces in full control of Kirkuk|website=www.aljazeera.com|accessdate=16 October 2017}}</ref> Following the capture of Kirkuk and [[Sinjar]],<ref name="KirkukIraq"/><ref>{{cite news|author1=Martin Chulov|title=Iraqi forces drive Kurdish fighters out of town of Sinjar|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2017/oct/17/iraqi-forces-drive-kurdish-fighters-out-of-sinjar|accessdate=18 November 2017}}</ref> [[Masoud Barzani]] announced his intentions to step down as [[President of Iraqi Kurdistan]], effective 1 November, after being in power for 12 years. His gamble of pushing through with the unofficial referendum ended with the disputed territories being recaptured by Iraq and with the Kurdish statebuilding project being left abandoned.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-middle-east-41794083|title=Iraqi Kurdish leader Massoud Barzani to step down|date=29 October 2017|accessdate=30 October 2017|publisher=BBC}}</ref>
Iraq [[Western Iraq campaign (2017–present)|captured]] ISIL's last two strongholds of [[Al-Qa'im (town)|Al-Qa'im]] and [[Rawa, Iraq|Rawah]]<ref>{{Cite news |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-mideast-crisis-iraq-syria-is/iraqi-forces-retake-border-crossing-with-syria-from-islamic-state-shiite-militias-say-idUSKBN1D30XE|title=Iraqi forces retake border crossing with Syria from Islamic State, Shi'ite militias say|date=2017-11-03|publisher=Reuters|access-date=2017-11-03}}</ref> on 17 November.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-middle-east-42026801|title=Iraq recaptures final IS-held town|date=17 November 2017|publisher=BBC News}}</ref> After the Iraqi army had captured the last ISIL-held areas in the al-Jazira desert bordering Syria, on 9 December the prime minister announced the end of the war.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-42291985|title=Iraq declares war with IS is over|date=2017-12-09|publisher=BBC News|access-date=2017-12-09|language=en-GB}}</ref><ref name="end of war">{{cite news |last=Mostafa |first=Nehal |date=9 December 2017 |title=Iraq announces end of war against IS, liberation of borders with Syria: Abadi |url=https://www.iraqinews.com/iraq-war/iraq-announces-end-war-liberation-borders-syria-abadi/ |work=Iraqi News |access-date=9 December 2017 }}</ref> A victory parade was held "in Baghdad's heavily fortified [[Green Zone]]" on the following day, and Prime Minister al-Abadi declared that 10 December would become a new annual holiday for Iraq.<ref name="victory parade">{{cite web|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-mideast-crisis-iraq-parade/iraq-holds-victory-parade-after-defeating-islamic-state-idUSKBN1E407Z|title=Iraq holds victory parade after defeating Islamic State|author=Ahmed Aboulenein|publisher=Reuters|date=10 December 2017|accessdate=11 December 2017|quote=An Iraqi military parade in Baghdad's heavily fortified Green Zone celebrated final victory over Islamic State on Sunday}}</ref> However, other government officials and sources, such as the [[Australian Government]], British Defence Secretary [[Gavin Williamson]], and [[Reuters]], warned that they expected ISIL to fight on by other means, such as [[guerilla warfare]] and [[terrorism]].<ref name=DOD-Australia2017-12-10a>{{cite web|url=https://www.minister.defence.gov.au/minister/marise-payne/media-releases/liberation-iraq-isis|title=Liberation Of Iraq From ISIS|author1=Malcolm Turnbull (Prime Minister)|authorlink1=Malcolm Turnbull|author2=Julie Bishop (Minister for Foreign Affairs)|authorlink2= Julie Bishop |author3=Marise Payne (Minister for Defence)|authorlink3=Marise Payne|date=10 December 2017|accessdate=11 December 2017|publisher=Department of Defence - Australian Government|quote=The Australian Government congratulates the people of Iraq after Prime Minister Haider Al-Abadi today announced that all areas of Iraq have been liberated from ISIS control. ... While today's announcement by the Iraqi government is an historic moment, Iraq's liberation does not mean the fight against terrorism and ISIS in Iraq is over. ISIS fighters who escaped capture will seek to conduct an insurgency to continue their legacy of death and destruction.}}</ref><ref name=DerbyshireTimes2017-12-10a>{{cite web|url=https://www.derbyshiretimes.co.uk/news/national/theresa-may-hails-historic-moment-as-islamic-state-is-driven-out-of-iraq-1-8902098|title=Theresa May hails 'historic moment' as Islamic State is driven out of Iraq|date=10 December 2017|accessdate=11 December 2017|publisher=Derbyshire Times|quote=Defence Secretary Gavin Williamson praised Iraqi achievements but said Islamic State remained a threat. "The fight though isn't over, as the group continue to pose a threat from across the Syrian border. "They can plan and inspire terrorist attacks, which rally their branches worldwide and continue to inspire others at home and abroad to do us harm.|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171211104924/https://www.derbyshiretimes.co.uk/news/national/theresa-may-hails-historic-moment-as-islamic-state-is-driven-out-of-iraq-1-8902098#|archive-date=2017-12-11|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref><ref name=Reuters2017-12-10a>{{cite web|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/wires/reuters/article-5164179/Iraq-holds-military-parade-celebrating-victory-Islamic-State.html|title=Iraq holds victory parade after defeating Islamic State|author1=Reuters|author2=Ahmed Aboulenein|date=10 December 2017|accessdate=11 December 2017|work=Daily Mail|publisher=Reuters |quote=BAGHDAD, Dec 10 (Reuters) - An Iraqi military parade in Baghdad's heavily fortified Green Zone celebrated final victory over Islamic State on Sunday, with Prime Minister Haider al-Abadi looking on as troops marched in formation, their bodies spelling "victory day" in Arabic. ... The forces fighting Islamic State in Iraq and Syria now expect a new phase of guerrilla warfare.}}</ref> Despite the victory announcements, ISIS retained its natural hideouts in [[Wadi Hauran]].<ref>{{cite web|author=The New Arab |url=https://www.alaraby.co.uk/english/news/2017/12/9/abadi-declares-end-of-war-against-is-in-iraq |title=Mission Accomplished: Abadi declares 'end of war against IS' in I |publisher=Alaraby.co.uk |date=2014-12-05 |accessdate=2018-05-06}}</ref>
== Aftermath == {{Main|Iraqi insurgency (2017–present)}} Although the civil war was declared over, ISIL continued a lower-scale [[insurgency]].
Months of relative calm in Baghdad ended with over 27 people killed by suicide bombers over a period of 3 days in mid-January 2018. Although there were no immediate claims of responsibility, it was reported that such attacks had usually been the work of the jihadist group Islamic State (IS) in the past, and that elements of the group were still active north of the city despite the government's claim of victory in December 2017.<ref name=CNN2018-01-15a>{{cite news|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2018/01/15/middleeast/baghdad-suicide-bombing/index.html|title=27 dead, dozens injured, in Baghdad double suicide bombing |author1=Euan McKirdy|author2=Hamdi Alkhshali |publisher=CNN |date=15 January 2018|accessdate=16 January 2018|quote=Monday marked the second deadly attack to hit the city in just three days. ... the city has experienced a period of relative calm for months.}}</ref><ref name=RTE2018-01-15a>{{cite news|url=https://www.rte.ie/news/world/2018/0115/933344-baghdad-bomb-blast/|title=27 killed, 64 wounded in Baghdad bomb blast |publisher=[[RTÉ]] |date=15 January 2018|accessdate=16 January 2018|quote=There was no immediate claim of responsibility, but most such attacks in Iraq are the work of the so-called Islamic State militant group. ... Elements of the group are still active north of Baghdad.}}</ref> On Wednesday January 17, two days after [[January 15, 2018 Baghdad bombings|the two suicide bombings on January 15]], IS "claimed responsibility for the twin suicide bombings in Baghdad this week", though the ''[[New York Times]]'' suggested that the delay, and a number of errors in the claim, may show that the group's "media apparatus has been disrupted".<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/01/17/world/middleeast/iraq-baghdad-isis-bombing.html|title=ISIS Claims Responsibility for Baghdad Bombings|last=Callimachi|first=Rukmini|date=2018|work=The New York Times|access-date=2018-01-21|last2=Coker|first2=Margaret|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331}}</ref>
''[[The Times]]'' meanwhile reported on 16 January that the Iraqi Army had launched an operation to oust ISIL from the Bosifian islands, a stronghold being used as a militant hideout. The hideout, located in [[Saladin governorate]], was discovered in December and is one of the 10 patches where the group is still active. About 100 militants were killed by Iraqi forces in the past one week.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.thetimes.co.uk/article/iraqi-army-attacks-isis-island-stronghold-tk33sg89z|title=Iraqi army attacks Isis island stronghold|first=Hannah Lucinda|last=Smith|date=January 16, 2018|accessdate=January 19, 2018}}</ref> An operation was launched on 7 February to hunt down the remnants of ISIL in [[Saladin Governorate]], as well as members of [[Jamaat Ansar al-Sunna|Ansar al-Sunna]] and the "[[White Flags]]", a new insurgent group<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.xinhuanet.com/english/2018-02/07/c_136956581.htm|title=Iraqi forces launch operation to hunt down rebels in Salahudin province|date=February 7, 2018|accessdate=February 10, 2018}}</ref> reportedly consisting of former ISIL members and Kurdish mafia groups.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.middleeasteye.net/news/iraq-islamic-state-white-flag-hashd-al-shaabi-1282818812|title=No surrender: 'White Flags' group rises as new threat in northern Iraq|first=Tom|last=Westcott|date=January 31, 2018|accessdate=February 10, 2018}}</ref>
[[File:Qaratapa self-defense group.png|thumb|left|Fighters of a [[self-defense]] group in northeastern Iraq in June 2018. ISIL still has a presence in remote areas of the country, often attacking small villages and forcing the locals to fight or flee.<ref name="new insurgency"/> ]]
Despite these efforts, ISIL continued to hold out in the western desert<ref>[https://www.almasdarnews.com/article/syrian-iraqi-border-completely-isis-free-first-time-years-map/ Syrian-Iraqi border is completely ISIS free for first time in years – map]</ref><ref>[https://www.iraqinews.com/iraq-war/iraqi-troops-destroy-is-arms-depot-three-missile-launchers-in-western-iraq/ Iraqi troops destroy IS arms depot, three missile launchers in western Iraq]</ref><ref>[https://www.iraqinews.com/iraq-war/400-is-militants-planning-to-resume-terrorist-activities-from-anbar-source/ 400 IS militants planning to resume terrorist activities from Anbar — source]</ref> and wage an insurgency campaign against government forces in northern Iraq by mid-2018, most notably in [[Diyala Governorate|Diyala]] and [[Kirkuk Governorate]]s. As the military could not protect the isolated hinterland of these regions, ISIL forces would repeatedly attack remote villages, defeating their self-defense groups, kidnap people for ransom and forcing local civilians to flee. Sometimes, ISIL fighters would even openly flaunt their presence, placing their flag at well visible points and driving around with motorcycles, cars, and technicals.<ref name="new insurgency">{{Cite web |url=https://www.voanews.com/a/iraqi-villagers-flee-their-homes-amid-new-islamic-state-insurgency/4437739.html |title=Iraqis Flee Homes Amid New IS Insurgency |author=Dilshad Anwar |work=[[Voice of America]] |date=13 June 2018 |accessdate=1 July 2018 }}</ref> The group also targeted followers of [[Yarsanism]] (called Kaka'i in Iraq) around Kirkuk, whom the militants consider unbelievers.<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.voanews.com/a/iraq-islamic-state-kakai-minority/4455712.html |title=IS Attacks Drive Members of Iraqi Kakai Minority From Their Villages |author=Dilshad Anwar |work=[[Voice of America]] |date=26 June 2018 |accessdate=1 July 2018 }}</ref> In course of one notable attack, ISIL fighters raided a house in a village to the south of Shirqat on 11 March 2018, killing a tribal sheikh who led a Sunni militia against the group as well as three others.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/world/islamic-state-attacks-kill-10-in-northern-iraq---police-10036882|title=Islamic State attacks kill 10 in northern Iraq - police |date=March 12, 2018|accessdate=March 23, 2018}}</ref> In July 2018, the Iraqi Army, Popular Mobilization Forces and Peshmerga launched Operation "Vengeance for the Martyrs" to destroy ISIL remnants in Diyala and Kirkuk Governorates, supported by the Iraqi Air Force and US-led coalition.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.al-monitor.com/pulse/contents/afp/2018/07/iraq-conflict-jihadists.html |title=Iraq launches major anti-IS operation after killings |author=[[Agence France-Presse]] |work=[[al-Monitor]] |date=4 July 2018 |accessdate=4 July 2018 }}</ref>
By April 2018, hundreds of ISIS fighters were still located in the Anbar desert.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://aawsat.com/english/home/article/1224591/iraqi-forces-kill-%E2%80%98isis-slaughterer%E2%80%99-anbar-desert |title=Iraqi Forces Kill ‘ISIS Slaughterer’ in Anbar Desert | Asharq AL-awsat |publisher=Aawsat.com |date=2018-04-02 |accessdate=2018-05-06}}</ref>
Following ISIL's defeat, the group has regardless continued an insurgency. However they have been greatly weakened and violence in Iraq has been sharply reduced in 2018. Only 95 people lost their lives during the month of May, the lowest figure in 10 years.<ref>http://www.cdobs.com/archive/featured/violence-in-iraq-at-lowest-level-in-10-years/</ref>
== Human rights == Nearly 19,000 civilians have been killed in Iraq in ISIL-linked violence between January 2014 and October 2015.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://edition.cnn.com/2016/01/19/middleeast/iraq-civilian-death-toll/ |title=Nearly 19,000 civilians killed in Iraq in 21-month period, report says |publisher=CNN |date=19 January 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161022084819/http://edition.cnn.com/2016/01/19/middleeast/iraq-civilian-death-toll/ |archivedate=22 October 2016 |df= }}</ref> [[Camp Speicher massacre|ISIL executed]] up to 1,700 Shia Iraqi Air Force cadets from [[Camp Speicher]] near Tikrit on 12 June 2014.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://edition.cnn.com/2015/04/06/middleeast/iraq-mass-graves/index.html|title=New mass graves found in Tikrit|publisher=CNN|last=Ellis|first=Ralph|date=6 April 2015 |deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150407003533/http://edition.cnn.com/2015/04/06/middleeast/iraq-mass-graves/index.html|archivedate=7 April 2015|df=}}</ref> The [[genocide of Yazidis by ISIL]] has led to the expulsion, flight and effective exile of the [[Yazidis|Yazidi]] people from their ancestral lands in northern Iraq.<ref>{{cite news |last=Arraf|first=Jane|date=7 August 2014|title=Islamic State persecution of Yazidi minority amounts to genocide, UN says|url=http://www.csmonitor.com/World/Middle-East/2014/0807/Islamic-State-persecution-of-Yazidi-minority-amounts-to-genocide-UN-says-video|newspaper=[[The Christian Science Monitor]] |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140808154839/http://www.csmonitor.com/World/Middle-East/2014/0807/Islamic-State-persecution-of-Yazidi-minority-amounts-to-genocide-UN-says-video|archivedate=8 August 2014|accessdate=8 August 2014}}</ref>
According to ''Newsweek'', [[Amnesty International]] claimed that "Iraqi government forces and paramilitary militias have tortured, arbitrarily detained, forcibly disappeared and executed thousands of civilians who have fled the rule of the Islamic State militant group".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://europe.newsweek.com/iraqi-civilians-fleeing-isis-mosul-face-torture-and-death-revenge-attacks-511128?rm=eu|title=Iraqi Civilians Fleeing ISIS in Mosul Face Torture and Death in Revenge Attacks: Amnesty|work=[[Newsweek]]|date=18 October 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161022024110/http://europe.newsweek.com/iraqi-civilians-fleeing-isis-mosul-face-torture-and-death-revenge-attacks-511128?rm=eu|archivedate=22 October 2016|df=}}</ref> The report, titled ''Punished for Daesh's crimes''', alleges that thousands of Sunni men and boys have been forcibly disappeared by Iraqi government forces and militias.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/middle-east/mosul-offensive-isis-iraq-army-torture-civilians-sunni-shia-revenge-killings-amnesty-report-a7366031.html |title=Mosul offensive: Iraqi-backed troops accused of torturing civilians ahead of operation to rid city of Isis |work=[[The Independent]] |date=18 October 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161022024042/http://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/middle-east/mosul-offensive-isis-iraq-army-torture-civilians-sunni-shia-revenge-killings-amnesty-report-a7366031.html |archivedate=22 October 2016 |df= }}</ref>
